sentence: All the more necessary this warning in that it must seize people with a certain sadness that, however much the world has changed, the concept of the tragic nevertheless remains essentially unchanged, just as weeping still comes no less naturally to man.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Reassuring as this may seem to one who wishes no divorce, let alone a separation, the same difficulty just circumvented reappears in another and even more dangerous form.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: No one at all familiar with modern aesthetics, and who therefore recognizes how closely Aristotle’s principles are adhered to and still constantly apply in modern aesthetics,2 will deny that we still keep on going back to Aristotelian aesthetics, not just from dutiful observance or force of habit.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But when we look more nearly at these principles the difficulties are immediately evident.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The criteria are quite general in kind, and one could easily agree entirely with Aristotle and yet in another sense disagree.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So as not to anticipate the discussion that follows by mentioning right at the start the subject that will provide its content, I shall illustrate what I mean by making the corresponding point about comedy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If an aesthetician of the past had said that what comedy presupposes is character and situation, and that what it gives rise to is laughter, this is something we can appeal to over and over again; but as soon as one reflects on how different the things can be that make people laugh, one is quickly apprised of the criterion’s colossal scope.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Anyone who has ever observed others’ or his own laughter, anyone who in the course of such observation has kept his eye less on accidental differences than on the general features, whoever has noted with psychological interest how different the things are that each generation finds laughable, will be readily convinced that this unchanging criterion of comedy – that it gives rise to laughter – embraces a high degree of change-ableness respecting how the world consciousness conceives the laughable, yet without the differences being so far-reaching that the bodily expression of laughter might be weeping.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The same, then, is true of the tragic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The gist of this little inquiry will, in the main, be not so much the relation between the ancient and the modern conception of the tragic, as an attempt to show how the special characteristic of ancient tragedy can be discerned in the modern, so that the true tragedy in the latter may come to light.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Yet however hard I try to ensure that it does come to light, I shall refrain from prophecies about this being what the age demands.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Nothing, then, will result from its corning to light; all the more so that the tendency of the whole age is rather towards comedy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Human existence is considerably undermined by doubt on the part of its subjects and isolation is consistently gaining the upper hand, the best confirmation of which is to take note of all the various social exertions.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: By aiming to oppose the tendency to isolation, such exertions serve only to confirm it, as far as they do so by adopting such misguided means.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: To be isolated is always to assert oneself numerically; when you assert yourself as one, that is isolation.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: I’m sure all friends of association will concur with me in this, even if they are incapable of seeing that just the same isolation obtains when hundreds want to assert themselves as nothing but hundreds.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: To a number itself the number is always a matter of indifference, whether it is one or a thousand or the whole world’s population specified merely as a number.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This spirit of association is therefore in principle just as revolutionary as the spirit it would counteract.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: When David wanted to savour properly his power and glory, he had his people counted.3 In our age you might say, on the contrary, that to feel their importance in the face of a greater power, people count themselves.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But all these associations bear the stamp of contingency and are usually formed for some accidental purpose or other, naturally that of the association itself.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The numerous associations thus prove the age’s dissolution, and themselves help to hasten it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: They are the infusoria in the organism of the state which indicate that it is indeed in dissolution.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: When did political clubs begin to be general in Greece if not just when the state was on the point of dissolution?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: And hasn’t our own age a remarkable similarity to the one which not even Aristophanes could make more ludicrous than in fact it was?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Hasn’t that invisible and spiritual bond loosened which held the state together politically?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Isn’t the power of religion, which held fast to the invisible, weakened and destroyed?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Haven’t the statesmen and clergy this in common, that like the augurs of old they find it hard to look at one another without smiling?4 Our age certainly has one peculiarity to a greater degree than Greece, namely that it is more melancholy and hence deeper in despair.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Our age is thus melancholy enough to realize there is something called responsibility and that it has some significance.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So while everyone wants to rule, no one wants the responsibility.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is still fresh in our memory that a French statesman, on being offered a portfolio for a second time, declared that he would accept on the condition that the secretary of state be made responsible.5 The King of France, we all know, has no responsibility, while his minister has; the minister does not want to be responsible but wants to be minister provided the secretary of state becomes responsible.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Naturally, the end result is that the watchmen or street wardens become responsible.6 What a subject for Aristophanes, this upside-down tale of responsibility!
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: On the other hand, why is it the government and rulers are so afraid of assuming responsibility, if not because they fear an opposition party that seeks to evade responsibility through its own ladder of command?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: When one imagines these two powers in mutual opposition but unable to come to grips with each other because the one constantly evades the other, because the one only makes its obeisances before the other, a set-up like that would certainly not lack comic effect.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This is enough to show that the real bonds of the state have dissolved, yet the isolation thus incurred is naturally comic, and the comedy is that subjectivity wants to assert itself as mere form.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: All isolated individuals always become comic by asserting their own accidental individuality in the face of evolutionary necessity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: There is no doubt that it would be most deeply comical to have some accidental individual come by the universal idea of wanting to be the saviour of the whole world.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: On the other hand, the appearance of Christ is in a certain sense the deepest tragedy (in another sense it is infinitely more), because Christ came in the fullness of time, and – a point I must particularly stress in connection with what follows – He bore the sins of all the world.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Aristotle, we know, mentions two things, dianoia and ethos [thought and character], as the source of the action in tragedy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But he remarks also that the main thing is the telos [end or completion], and the individuals do not act in order to portray characters but the latter are included for the sake of the action.7 One quickly notes a departure here from modern tragedy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The peculiarity of ancient tragedy is that the action does not proceed from character alone, that the action is not reflected enough in the acting subject, but has a relative admixture of suffering.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Nor is it the case that ancient tragedy has developed dialogue to the point of exhaustive reflection, so that everything can be absorbed in that.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In the monologue and the chorus it does in fact possess the separate elements of dialogue.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Whether the chorus approaches the substantiality of epic or the exaltation of lyric, it still points in a way to that extra which will not be absorbed in individuality.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The monologue, for its part, has more of the concentration of lyric and its extra is what will not be absorbed in action and situation.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In ancient tragedy the action itself possesses an epic feature; it is just as much event as action.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The reason is of course to be found in the fact that in the ancient world subjectivity was not fully conscious and reflective.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Even though the individual moved freely, he still depended on substantial categories, on state, family, and destiny.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This category of the substantial is the authentically fatalistic element in Greek tragedy, and its true peculiarity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The hero’s downfall is therefore not the outcome simply of his own action, it is also a suffering, while in modern tragedy the downfall of the hero is really not suffering but action.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In modem times, therefore, it is really situation and character that predominate.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The tragic hero is subjectively reflected in himself, and this reflection hasn’t simply refracted him out of every immediate relation to state, race, and destiny, often it has refracted him even out of his own preceding life.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: What interests us is some certain definite moment of his life as his own deed.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Because of this, the tragic element can be exhaustively represented in situation and words, there being nothing whatever left over of the immediate.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Hence modern tragedy has no epic foreground, no epic heritage.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The hero stands and falls entirely on his own deeds.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The significance of this brief but adequate account is to illuminate a difference between ancient and modern tragedy which I consider of great importance: the different kinds of tragic guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Aristotle, as we know, requires the tragic hero to have hamartia [guilt]8.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But just as the action in Greek tragedy is something intermediate between activity and passivity, so too is the guilt, and in this lies the tragic collision.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: On the other hand, the more the subjectivity becomes reflected, or the more one sees the individual, in the Pelagian manner, left to himself, the more the guilt becomes ethical.9 Between these two extremes lies the tragic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If the individual is entirely without guilt, the tragic interest is removed, for the tragic collision loses its power.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If, on the other hand, he is guilty absolutely, he can no longer interest us tragically.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So it is surely a misunderstanding of the tragic that our age strives to have the whole tragic destiny become transubstantiated in individuality and subjectivity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: One turns a deaf ear on the hero’s past life, one throws his whole life upon his shoulders as his own doing, makes him accountable for everything; but in so doing one also transforms his aesthetic guilt into an ethical guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The tragic hero thus becomes bad.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Evil becomes the real object of tragedy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But evil has no aesthetic interest, and sin is not an aesthetic element.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: No doubt this mistaken endeavour has its origin in the whole tendency of our age to work towards the comic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The comic is to be found precisely in the isolation.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If you try to let the tragic take effect inside this isolation, you get the evil in all its baseness, not the properly tragic guilt in its ambiguous innocence.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It isn’t hard to find examples when one looks about in modern literature.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Thus that in many ways brilliant work of Grabbe’s, Faust und Don Juan, is really built around the notion of evil.10 However, so as not to argue from just a single work, I shall indicate this instead in the general consciousness of the age as a whole.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If one wanted to portray someone upon whom an unhappy childhood had had so disturbing an effect that the experiences in question were the cause of his downfall, a thing like that would simply have no appeal for the present age – and not of course because it was badly handled, for I can certainly take for granted that it would be handled with distinction, but because our age sets another standard.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It won’t listen to such effeminacy; it holds the individual responsible for his own life, without further ado.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So if he goes to the dogs it isn’t tragic but bad.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It leads you to think this must be a kingdom of gods, this generation in which I too have the honour to live.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: However, that is by no means the case; the energy, the courage, which would thus be the creator of its own fortune, yes, the creator of itself, is an illusion and in losing the tragic the age gains despair.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: There is a sadness and a healing power in the tragic which truly one should not despise, and when one wants, in the larger-than-life manner of our age, to gain oneself, one loses oneself and becomes comical.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Every individual, however original, is still a child of God, of his age, of his nation, of his family, of his friends.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Only thus does he have his truth.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If in all this relativity he tries to be the absolute, he becomes ridiculous.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In language one sometimes finds a word which, used in a particular case because of the construction, ends up by having independence declared on its behalf, if you will, as an adverb in that particular case.11 For the experts a word like this acquires an emphasis and weakness it never recovers from.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Should it seek recognition as a substantive all the same and insist on its right to be inflected in all five cases, it would be truly comic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: And so, too, with the individual when, fetched perhaps with difficulty from the womb of time, he wants in this monstrous relativity to be absolute.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But if he renounces the claim of the absolute in order to become relative, then eo ipso the tragic is his, even if he were the happiest of individuals; indeed I would say that it is only when the individual has the tragic that he becomes happy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The tragic contains an infinite leniency; really it is what divine love and mercy are, but from the aesthetic perspective on human life; it is even milder, and so I would say it was a maternal love which soothes the troubled.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The ethical is strict and harsh.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So if a criminal pleads to the judge that his mother had a propensity for stealing, and particularly at the time she was carrying him, the judge secures the Board of Health’s opinion of his mental condition and decides that what he is dealing with is a thief and not a thief’s mother.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Since we are talking about a crime, the sinner can’t very well flee to the temple of aesthetics, and yet the aesthetic will put in an extenuating word for him.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Still, it would be wrong for him to seek comfort there, for his path leads him not to the aesthetic but to the religious.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The aesthetic lies behind him, and it would be a new sin for him now to grasp at the aesthetic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The religious is the expression of a paternal love, since it contains the ethical but in a mollified form.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: And mollified by what?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Precisely by what gives the tragic its leniency: continuity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But while the aesthetic gives this pause before the profound opposition of sin is pressed home, the religious does not give it until after this opposition is seen in all its fearfulness.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Just when the sinner is about to sink under the general sin which he has taken upon himself, because he felt that the more guilty he became the better his prospects for salvation – in that same moment of terror, consolation appears in the fact that it is a general sinfulness which has asserted itself, now also in him.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But this is a religious consolation, and he who thinks to attain it in some other way, for instance by aesthetic volatilization, has taken this consolation in vain and doesn’t really possess it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In a sense, then, it is a very proper tactic of the age to hold the individual responsible for everything.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But the unfortunate thing is that the age does not do it deeply and inwardly enough, and hence its vacillation.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It has enough conceit of itself to disdain tragedy’s tears, but it also has enough self-conceit to dispense with divine mercy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But then what is human life when we take these two things away?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: What is the human race?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Either the sadness of the tragic, or the profound sorrow and profound joy of religion.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Or is that not the peculiarity of everything that emanates from that happy people – a melancholy, a sadness, in its art, in its poetry, in its life, in its joy?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In the preceding I have mainly sought to underline the difference between ancient and modern tragedy, so far as this becomes clear in differences in the tragic hero’s guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This is really the focus from which all other characteristic differences radiate.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If the hero is unequivocally guilty, the monologue disappears and with it destiny.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The thought is transparent in the dialogue, and the action in the situation.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The same can be put from another point of view with regard to the mood evoked by the tragedy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Aristotle, as we know, requires that tragedy should arouse fear and pity in the spectator.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: I recollect that Hegel aligns himself with this view in his Aesthetics and embarks on a double, though not particularly exhaustive, reflection on each of these points.12 In respect of Aristotle’s distinction between fear and pity, one could interpret fear as the mood accompanying the particular event, and pity as the mood forming the definite impression.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is the latter that I have most in mind, because it is this that corresponds to tragic guilt, and so it has the same dialectic as that concept.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Now Hegel observes in this connection that there are two kinds of compassion, the ordinary kind concerned with the finite aspect of suffering, and true tragic pity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This, indeed, is correct, but for me of less importance, since the common emotion is a misunderstanding which can just as well apply to ancient as to modern tragedy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: What Hegel adds regarding true pity, however, is straight to the point: ‘True pity, on the contrary, is sympathy at the same time with the sufferer’s justification.’13 While Hegel considers compassion in general and its differences in individual variation, I prefer to underline differences in compassion as they are related to differences in tragic guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: To make the point in a trice I shall let the passion in the word ‘compassion’ be split up and ascribe the sympathy which the word expresses to every man, without saying anything about the mood of the spectator that might be traced to his contingency but in such a way that, in explaining the difference in his mood, I also express the difference in the tragic guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In ancient tragedy the sorrow is deeper, the pain less; in modern tragedy, the pain is greater, the sorrow less.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Sorrow always contains something more substantial than pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Pain always indicates a reflection on suffering which sorrow does not know.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is very interesting, from a psychological standpoint, to watch a child when it sees an older person suffer.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The child hasn’t sufficient reflection to feel pain, and yet its sorrow is infinitely deep.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It hasn’t sufficient reflection to have a conception of sin and guilt, so when it sees an older person suffer, it does not occur to it to think about it, and yet when the cause of the suffering is concealed from it, there is a dim presentiment of it in its sorrow.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Such too, though in complete and profound harmony, is the Greek sorrow, and that is why it is at one and the same time so gentle and so deep.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But when an older person sees someone younger, a child, suffer, his pain is greater, his sorrow less.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The more clear the conception of guilt, the greater the pain and the less profound the sorrow.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Applying this, then, to the relation between ancient and modern tragedy, one has to say: in ancient tragedy, the sorrow is deeper, and in the corresponding consciousness, too, the sorrow is deeper.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: For one must always bear in mind that the sorrow lies not in me, but in the tragedy, and that to understand the deep sorrow of Greek tragedy I must enter into the Greek consciousness.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Often, then, it is surely only affectation when so many people profess to admire Greek tragedy; for it is obvious that our age has at least no great sympathy with the real character of Greek sorrow.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The sorrow of Greek tragedy is deeper because the guilt has the ambiguity of the aesthetic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In modem times the pain is greater.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God,14 that is what one might say about Greek tragedy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The wrath of the gods is terrible, yet the pain is not so great as in modern tragedy, where the hero suffers all his guilt, is transparent to himself in his own suffering of his guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Here, as with tragic guilt, we must show what is the true aesthetic sorrow and what the true aesthetic pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Now, obviously the bitterest pain is remorse, but remorse has an ethical, not an aesthetic, reality.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is the bitterest pain because it has all of guilt’s total transparency, but just because of this transparency it has no aesthetic interest.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Remorse has a holiness which obscures the aesthetic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It won’t be seen, least of all by the spectator, and it requires quite a different kind of self-activity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: True, modern comedy has sometimes presented remorse on the stage, but this just shows lack of judgement on the part of the author.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Perhaps it has to do with the thought of the psychological interest one may have in seeing remorse portrayed, but then again, psychological interest is not the aesthetic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This is part of the confusion evident in so many ways in our age: we look for a thing where we ought not to look for it; and worse, we find it where we ought not to find it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: We want to be edified in the theatre, to be influenced aesthetically in church, to be converted by novels, to enjoy books of devotion; we want philosophy in the pulpit and the preacher in the professorial chair.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This pain is accordingly not aesthetic pain, yet clearly it is this the modern age works towards as its highest tragic interest.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The same is true of tragic guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Our age has lost all the substantial categories of family, state and race.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It has to leave the individual entirely to himself, so that in a stricter sense he becomes his own creator.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: His guilt is therefore sin, his pain remorse.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But the tragic is then done away with.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: And what is, in a stricter sense, the tragedy of suffering has really lost its tragic interest, for the power from which the suffering comes has lost its meaning, and the spectator cries: ‘Heaven helps those who help themselves!’ In other words, the spectator has lost his compassion.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But compassion is, in an objective as well as a subjective sense, the authentic expression of the tragic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: For clarity’s sake, and before going further with this account, I shall identify true aesthetic sorrow a little more closely.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Sorrow has the opposite movement to that of pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So long as one doesn’t spoil things out of a misplaced mania for consistency – something I shall prevent also in another way – one may say: the more innocence, the deeper the sorrow.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If you press this too far, you destroy the tragic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: There is always an element of guilt left over, but it is never properly reflected in the subject; which is why in Greek tragedy the sorrow is so deep.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In order to prevent misplaced consistency, I shall merely remark that exaggeration only succeeds in carrying the matter over into another sphere.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The synthesis of absolute innocence and absolute guilt is not an aesthetic feature but a metaphysical one.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This is the real reason why people have always been ashamed to call the life of Christ a tragedy; one feels instinctively that aesthetic categories do not exhaust the matter.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is clear in another way, too, that Christ’s life amounts to more than can be exhausted in aesthetic terms, namely from the fact that these terms neutralize themselves in this phenomenon, and are rendered irrelevant.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Tragic action always contains an element of suffering, and tragic suffering an element of action; the aesthetic lies in the relativity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The identity of an absolute action and an absolute suffering is beyond the powers of aesthetics and belongs to metaphysics.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This identity is exemplified in the life of Christ, for His suffering is absolute because the action is absolutely free, and His action is absolute suffering because it is absolute obedience.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The element of guilt that is always left over is, accordingly, not subjectively reflected and this makes the sorrow deep.

sentence: Tragic guilt is more than just subjective guilt, it is inherited guilt.

sentence: But inherited guilt, like original sin, is a substantial category, and it is just this substantiality that makes the sorrow deeper.

sentence: Sophocles’ celebrated tragic trilogy, Oedipus at Colonus, Oedipus Rex and Antigone, turns essentially on this authentic tragic interest.

sentence: But inherited guilt contains the self-contradiction of being guilt yet not being guilt.

sentence: The bond that makes the individual guilty is precisely piety, but the guilt which he thereby incurs has all possible aesthetic ambiguity.

sentence: One might well conclude that the people who developed profound tragedy were the Jews.

sentence: Thus, when they say of Jehovah that he is a jealous God who visits the sins of the fathers on the children unto the third and the fourth generations,15 or one hears those terrible imprecations in the Old Testament, one might feel tempted to look here for the material of tragedy.

sentence: But Judaism is too ethically developed for this.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Jehovah’s curses, terrible as they are, are nevertheless also righteous punishment.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Such was not the case in Greece, there the wrath of the gods has no ethical character, but aesthetic ambiguity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In Greek tragedy itself we find a transition from sorrow to pain, and as an example of this I must mention the Philoctetes.16 This is, in the stricter sense, a tragedy of suffering.

sentence: But here, too, there is a high degree of objectivity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The Greek hero reposes in his fate, his fate is unchangeable, there is nothing further to be said about it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This factor furnishes the element of sorrow in the pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The first doubt with which pain really begins is this: why has this befallen me, why can it not be otherwise?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is true that in the Philoctetes there is – and this is something that has always struck me as remarkable and as essentially distinguishing this piece from the immortal trilogy – a high degree of reflection: the masterly portrayal of the self-contradiction in his pain, which contains so deep a human truth while an objectivity still sustains the whole.17 Philoctetes’ reflection doesn’t become absorbed in itself, and it is typically Greek that he complains that no one understands his pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: There is an exceptional truth in this, and yet it is just here that the difference shows between his pain and the reflective pain that always wants to be alone in its pain, which seeks a new pain in this solitude of pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: True tragic sorrow accordingly requires an element of guilt, true tragic pain an element of innocence.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: True tragic sorrow requires an element of transparency, true tragic pain an element of opaqueness.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This I believe best indicates the dialectic in which the categories of sorrow and pain come in contact with each other, as well as the dialectic inherent in the concept of tragic guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Seeing it is contrary to the spirit of our Society to produce closely coherent works or greater wholes.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Seeing it is not our purpose to labour upon a Tower of Babel which God in His righteousness can descend upon and destroy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Seeing that we, conscious of the justness of that confusion of tongues, recognize the fragmentary as a characteristic of all human striving in its truth and realize that it is precisely this that distinguishes it from the infinite coherence of Nature, that an individual’s wealth consists precisely in his power of fragmentary extravagance, and that the producer’s enjoyment is also that of the receiver, not the laborious and meticulous execution, nor the protracted apprehension of this execution, but rather the production and enjoyment of that gleaming transience which for the producer contains something more than the completed effort, since it is the appearance of the Idea, and which for the recipient, too, contains a surplus, seeing that its fulguration awakens his own productivity – since all this, I say, is contrary to our Society’s penchant (and since, indeed, even the period just read could well be regarded as a disquieting attack upon the interjectory style in which the idea breaks out but without breaking through, a style which in our Society is accorded official status), then, having called attention to the fact that my conduct still cannot be called rebellious, seeing that the bond holding this period together is so loose that the intermediary clauses stand out in a sufficiently aphoristic and arbitrary manner, I shall merely call to mind that my style has made an attempt to appear to be what it is not – revolutionary.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This Society demands at every one of its meetings a renewal and rebirth, and for the following reason: that its inner activity may be rejuvenated by a new description of its productivity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Let us then describe our purpose as essays in the fragmentary endeavour, or in the art of writing posthumous papers.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: A fully completed work has no relation to the poetic personality; with posthumous papers one constantly feels, because of their broken-off, desultory character, a need to imagine the personality as being a part.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Posthumous papers are like a ruin, and what haunt could be more natural for the interred?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The art is therefore artistically to produce the same effect, the same carelessness and contingency, the same anacoluthic flight of thought.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The art is to produce an enjoyment which never actually becomes present, but always has in it an element of the past, so that it is present in the past.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This is already expressed in the word ‘posthumous’.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In a sense everything a writer produces is posthumous, yet one would never think of calling a completed work posthumous, even if it possessed the accidental quality of not having been published in his lifetime.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Also, it is, I assume, a characteristic of all human productivity, as we have apprehended it, that it is an inheritance, since it is not men’s privilege to live in the everlasting sight of the gods.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Inheritance [Efterladenskab] is therefore what I shall call what is produced among us, an artistic inheritance; negligence [Efterladenhed], indolence, I shall call the genius that we appreciate; vis inertiae,18 the natural law that we worship.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In saying this I have complied with our sacred customs and rules.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So draw nearer to me, dear Symparanekromenoi, gather round me as I send my tragic heroine out into the world, as I give to the daughter of sorrow as her wedding gift a dowry of pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: She is my creation, yet her outline is so vague, her form so nebulous, that each one of you is free to fall for her and to love her in your own way.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: She is my creation, her thoughts are my thoughts, and yet it is as if I had lain with her in a night of love, as if she had entrusted me with her deep secret, breathed forth both it and her soul in my embrace, and as if the same instant she was transformed before me, had vanished so that her reality could only be traced in the mood that lingered on; instead of the opposite being true, that she was born to greater and greater reality from my own mood.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: I put words in her mouth, and yet to me it is as though I abused her confidence, she seems to stand reproachfully behind me; yet it is the other way around, in her secrecy she becomes more and more visible.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: She is my possession, my lawful possession, and yet sometimes it is as if I had crept into her confidence, slyly, as if I must constantly look round to find her behind me; and yet it is the other way around, she is constantly in front of me, she comes into existence only when I bring her forth.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: She is called Antigone.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This name I retain from the ancient tragedy, which in general I shall follow, except that everything will be modern.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But first a remark.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: I use a feminine figure because I really believe that a feminine nature is best suited to showing the difference.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: As a woman, she will have the substantiality needed for sorrow to be revealed, but as a member of a reflective world, she will have reflection enough to experience pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In order to experience sorrow, tragic guilt must vacillate between guilt and innocence; what conveys the guilt into her consciousness must always be some substantial feature.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But since, in order to experience sorrow, tragic guilt must have this vagueness, reflection must not be present in its infinitude, for then it would refract her out of her guilt, since reflection in its infinite subjectivity cannot allow the element of inherited guilt to which sorrow is due to remain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Since, however, her reflection is awakened, it will not refract her out of her sorrow but into it, at every moment transforming her sorrow into pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Labdacus’s family, then, is the object of the angry gods’ indignation.19 Oedipus has killed the sphinx, liberated Thebes; he has murdered his father, married his mother, and Antigone is the fruit of that marriage.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Thus it is with the Greek tragedy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Here I depart from it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: I keep all the facts of the case just as they are, yet everything is different.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: That he has slain the sphinx and liberated Thebes, we all know.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: And Oedipus lives honoured and admired, happy in his marriage with Jocasta.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The rest is concealed from the eyes of men, and no presentiment has ever summoned this horrible nightmare out into reality.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Only Antigone knows it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: How she has come to know it falls outside the tragic interest, and everyone is free to concoct his own explanation.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: At an early age, before she is yet fully matured, vague suspicions of this horrible secret have now and then gripped her soul, until with a single blow certainty casts her into the arms of anxiety.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Here, straightaway, I am given my definition of the modern idea of the tragic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: For anxiety is a reflection, and in this it differs essentially from sorrow.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Anxiety is the organ through which the subject appropriates sorrow and assimilates it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Anxiety is the energy of the movement by which sorrow bores its way into the heart.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But the movement is not swift like the arrow’s, it is gradual.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is not once and for all, but in constant becoming.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: As a passionate, erotic glance desires its object, anxiety looks at sorrow in order to desire it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: As a quiet, incorruptible glance of love is preoccupied with the beloved object, anxiety preoccupies itself with sorrow.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But anxiety contains something extra which makes it cling even more strongly to its object, for it both loves and fears it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Anxiety has a double function.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is the movement of discovery that constantly touches, and by fingering it, discovers sorrow by going around it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Or anxiety is sudden, positing the whole sorrow in the here and now, yet in such a way that this here and now instantly dissolves into succession.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Anxiety in this sense is a genuinely tragic category, and this is where the old saying quern deus vult perdere, primum dementat20 comes properly into its own.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The fact that anxiety is a phenomenon of reflection is something language itself indicates; for I always say ‘to be anxious about something’, thus separating the anxiety from that about which I am anxious; I can never use anxiety to refer to its object.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Whereas, if I say ‘my sorrow’, this, on the contrary, can express what I sorrow over just as much as my sorrow over it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Anxiety, furthermore, always involves a reflection upon time, for I cannot be anxious about the present, only about the past or the future; but the past and the future, holding on to each other so tightly that the present vanishes, are reflective phenomena.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Greek sorrow, on the contrary, like the whole of Greek life, is in the present tense, and therefore the sorrow is deeper but the pain less.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So anxiety is essential to the tragic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Hence Hamlet is deeply tragic because he suspects his mother’s guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Robert le Diable asks how he could ever have come to cause so much evil.21 Hogne, whom his mother had begotten with a troll, happening to see his image in the water, asks his mother how his body acquired such a shape.22 The difference is now plain to see.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In the Greek tragedy Antigone is not at all concerned about her father’s unhappy destiny.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This rests like an impenetrable sorrow over the whole family.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Antigone lives as carefree a life as any other young Greek girl; indeed the chorus pities her, seeing her death is preordained, because she is to quit this life at so early an age, quit it without having tasted its most beautiful joys, evidently forgetting the family’s own deep sorrow.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: That doesn’t at all imply frivolity, or mean that the particular individual stands alone by himself, unconcerned with his relationship to the family.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is authentically Greek.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Life-relationships are assigned to them once and for all, just like the heaven under which they live.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If that is dark and cloudy it is also unchangeable.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It gives the soul a keynote, and that is sorrow, not pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In Antigone, tragic guilt focuses on a definite point: that she had buried her brother in defiance of the king’s prohibition.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If this is seen as an isolated fact, as a collision between sisterly affection and piety and an arbitrary human prohibition, then the Antigone would cease to be a Greek tragedy, it would be an altogether modern tragic subject.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: What in the Greek sense provides tragic interest is the fact that, in the brother’s unhappy death, in the sister’s collision with a single human circumstance, there is a re-echoing of Oedipus’s sorry fate; it is, one might say, the afterpains, the tragic destiny of Oedipus, ramifying in every branch of his family.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This totality makes the spectator’s sorrow infinitely deep.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is not an individual that goes under, but a little world; the objective sorrow, set free, now strides forward with its own terrible consistency, like a force of nature, and Antigone’s sorry fate is like an echo of her father’s, an intensified sorrow.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So when Antigone, in defiance of the king’s prohibition, resolves to bury her brother, we see in this not so much a free action on her part as a fateful necessity which visits the sins of the fathers on the children.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: There is indeed enough freedom here to make us love Antigone for her sisterly love, but in the necessity of fate there is also, as it were, a higher refrain enveloping not just the life of Oedipus, but all his family too.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So while the Greek Antigone lives a life free enough from care for us to imagine her life in its gradual unfolding as even being a happy one if this new fact had not emerged, our Antigone’s life is, on the contrary, essentially over.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is no stingy endowment I have given her, and as we say that an aptly spoken word is like apples of gold in pictures of silver, so here have I placed the fruit of sorrow in a cup of pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Her dowry is not a vain splendour which moth and rust can corrupt,23 it is an eternal treasure.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Thieves cannot break in and steal it; she herself will be too vigilant for that.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Her life does not unfold like that of the Greek Antigone; it is not turned outward but inward.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The scene is not external but internal, a scene of the spirit.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Have I not succeeded, dear Symparanekromenoi, in arousing your interest in such a girl, or must I resort to a captatio benevolentiae?24 She, too, does not belong to the world she lives in; however flourishing and healthy, her real life is clandestine.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: She, too, though living, has in another sense departed; quiet is that life and hidden, not even a sigh does the world hear, for her sigh is hidden in the privacy of her soul.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: I need not remind you that she is by no means a weak and sickly woman, quite the contrary, she is vigorous and proud.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Perhaps nothing ennobles a human being so much as keeping a secret.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It gives a man’s whole life a meaning, though one that it has only for him.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It saves him from every vain regard for his environment; sufficient unto himself, he rests blessed in his secret – we can almost say that, even if his secret were the most sinister.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Such is our Antigone.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Proud of her secret, proud that she has been chosen to save in so remarkable a manner the honour and esteem of the house of Oedipus; and when the grateful people cheer Oedipus and applaud him, she is conscious of the role she is playing, and her secret sinks deeper into her soul, even more inaccessible to any living being.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: She feels how much has been placed in her hands, and this gives her the larger-than-life dimension needed for her to engage us as a tragic personality.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: She must interest us as an individual figure.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: More than just a common young girl, she is yet a young girl; she is a bride, but in all innocence and purity.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: As a bride, woman achieves her destiny, and ordinarily a woman can interest us only to the degree that she is brought into relation to this her destiny.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But there are analogies here.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: One says of a bride of God that it is faith and spirit that provide the substance in which she rests.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: I would call our Antigone a bride in perhaps an even more beautiful sense, indeed she is almost more than that, she is mother; in the purely aesthetic sense she is virgo mater,25 she bears her secret under her heart, out of sight and undetected.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: She is silence precisely because she is secretive, but this self-withdrawal, implicit in silence, makes her larger than life.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Proud of her sorrow, she is jealous over it, for her sorrow is her love.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Yet her sorrow is not a dead, immovable possession: it is constantly in motion, it gives birth to pain and is born in pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: As when a girl resolves to dedicate her life to an idea, when she stands there with the sacrificial wreath upon her brow she is a bride, for the great inspirational idea transforms her and the votive wreath is like a bridal garland.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: She knows not any man, yet she is a bride; she knows not even the idea that inspires her, for that would be unwomanly.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Yet she is a bride.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Such is our Antigone, the bride of sorrow.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: She consecrates her life to sorrow over her father’s destiny, over her own.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: A misfortune such as has overtaken her father calls for sorrow, yet there is no one who can grieve over it, because there is no one who has knowledge of it.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: And as the Greek Antigone cannot bear to have her brother’s corpse flung away without the last honours, so she feels how cruel it would be should no one come to know of this; it troubles her that no tears should be shed; she practically thanks the gods because she has been chosen as this instrument.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Thus is Antigone great in her pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Here, too, I can indicate a difference between Greek and modern tragedy.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: It is genuinely Greek for Philoctetes to complain that there is no one who knows what he suffers; it is an expression of a deep human need to want others to realize this.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Reflective grief, however, has no such desire; it does not occur to Antigone to wish that anyone should learn of her pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But she feels it in relation to her father, she feels the justice of having to suffer grief, which is just as proper aesthetically as that a man should suffer punishment if he has done wrong.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So while it is the idea of her being about to be buried alive that first wrings from the Antigone of the Greek tragedy this outburst of grief:     O hapless alien,   Lodged with neither mortal man nor corpse,   Not with the living nor yet with the dead,26 our own Antigone can say this about herself all her life.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The difference is striking; there is a factual truth in the former’s assertion that makes the pain less.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If our Antigone were to say the same, it would be unreal, but it is this unreality which is the real pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The Greeks do not express themselves figuratively, precisely because the reflection that goes with this was not present in their lives.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So when Philoctetes complains that he lives solitary and forsaken on a desert island, what he says is also an outward truth.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But when our Antigone feels pain in her solitude, it is only in a figurative sense that she is alone.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Yet just for that reason, her pain is real pain.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: As far as the tragic guilt goes, on the one hand it lies in the fact that she buries her brother, but also partly in the context of her father’s sorry fate, which is presupposed from the two preceding tragedies.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Here again I come to the peculiar dialectic which puts the guilt of Oedipus’s house in relation to the individual.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This is hereditary guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Dialectics is commonly considered fairly abstract; one thinks usually of logical steps.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: However, one soon learns from life that there are many kinds of dialectic, that nearly every passion has its own.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: So the dialectic which puts the guilt of the race or family in connection with the particular subject, so that the latter is not just a passive sufferer under it – for that is a natural consequence one would try in vain to steel oneself against – but bears the guilt along with the suffering, participates in it, this dialectic is foreign to us, does not compel us.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But if one were to envisage a rebirth out of ancient tragedy, then every individual would have to be concerned about his own rebirth, not just in a spiritual sense, but in the definite sense of a rebirth from the womb of family and race.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: The dialectic which puts the individual in connection with family and race is no subjective dialectic, for what that does is precisely to remove the connection and take the individual out of the network of relationships.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: No, it is an objective dialectic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Essentially it is piety, and to preserve piety cannot be considered in any way harmful to the individual.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: In our time one allows in respect of nature what one is loth to allow in matters of spirit.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: Still, one would not wish to be so isolated, so unnatural, as not to regard the family as a whole, of which one must say that if one member suffers, then all suffer.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This one does involuntarily, and why else should a particular individual fear lest another member of the family brings disgrace upon it, if not because he feels that he, too, will suffer the disgrace?
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This suffering the individual must obviously take along with him, whether he wants to or not.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: But since the point of departure here is the individual not the family, this enforced suffering is maximum; one senses that mankind cannot be complete master over its natural circumstances, yet still wants to be so as far as possible.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If, on the other hand, the individual looks on the natural tie as a factor involved in his own truth, the way to express this in the spiritual world is: the individual participates in the guilt.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: This is an implication many people would perhaps be unable to grasp, but then neither could they grasp the tragic.
chapter_text: Ancient Tragedys Rreflection in the Modern

sentence: If the individual is isolated, he is either absolutely the creator of his own destiny, in which case nothing tragic remains, but only the evil – for it is not even tragic for an individual to be blinded by or engrossed in himself, it is his own doing – or individuals are nothing but modifications of the eternal substance of existence, and so once again the tragic is lost.

sentence: 4 SHADOWGRAPHS  Psychological Entertainment     Read before Symparanekromenoi     Love may always breach its oath;   Love’s spell in this cave does lull       The drunken, startled soul   Into forgetting it pledged its troth.
* Yesterday I loved, Today I suffer, Tomorrow I die.
Yet fain would I think Today and tomorrow, Of yesterday.1 IMPROVISED ADDRESS We celebrate, in this hour, the founding of our Society.
We rejoice once more at the recurrence of the happy event of the longest day’s passing and the commencement of the victory of night.
This long, livelong day we have waited; even a moment ago we were sighing at its length, but now our despair is turned to joy.
True, the victory is but trifling and the day will remain in the ascendant yet a while, but the fact that its dominion has been broken does not escape us.
So we do not put off our celebrations until night’s victory can be seen by all, do not wait until the sluggish bourgeois life reminds us that the day is waning.

No, as a young bride impatiently awaits nightfall, we longingly await the first onset of night, the first announcement of its coming victory, and the nearer we approach despair at what to do should the days not shorten, the greater our joy and surprise.
A year has passed and our Society is still in being.
Shall we rejoice at this fact, dear Symparanekromenoi, rejoice that its survival mocks our teaching that everything must end?

Or should we not rather sorrow over the fact that it is still there, and be glad that in any case it has just one more year to go, seeing we decided to dissolve it if it had not vanished of itself before then?

– In founding it we have formed no far-reaching plans, for knowing life’s misery and the perfidy of existence we are resolved to lend the law of the world a hand and destroy ourselves if it does not get there first.
A year has passed and our numbers are still complete, no vacancies have occurred.
And none has been made; we are each of us too proud for that, for we all look upon death as the greatest good fortune.
Should we rejoice over this and not rather sorrow, and be glad only in the hope that life’s tumult will soon separate us, that life’s storm will soon snatch us away?
Thoughts like these are indeed better suited to our Society, accord best with the moment’s celebration, with the whole setting.

For is it not a stroke of genius and a matter of significance that the floor of this little room, according to the custom of the land, should be strewn with green as though for a funeral, and does not the nature that surrounds us itself lend its approval if we heed the wild storm raging around us, the mighty voice of the wind?

Yes, let us be silent for a moment and listen to the music of the storm, its sturdy course, its bold challenge, the defiant roaring of the ocean, and the anguished sighing of the forest, the despairing creaking of the trees, and the faint-hearted rustling of the grass.
It is true men say the divine voice is not in the rushing wind but in the gentle breeze,2 but our ears are not made to pick up gentle breezes, only to gulp in the din of the elements.
And why does it not break forth in still greater violence, making an end of life and the world and this brief speech, which at least has the supreme advantage that it is soon ended!

Yes, let that vortex which is the innermost principle of the world, even though people are not aware of it but busily eat and drink and marry and propagate without a heed, let it break forth and in its resentment shrug off the mountains and the nations and the cultural achievements and clever inventions of man, let it break forth with the last terrible shriek, which more surely than the last trump proclaims the overthrow of everything, let it move and whirl away this naked cliff on which we stand, as easily as fluff before the breath of our nostrils.3 – And yet night is winning and the day is shortening and hope is growing!
So fill your cups once more, dear drinking companions; with this goblet I toast you, the eternal mother of all things, silent night!4 From you all things come, to you they all return.
Then take pity once more upon the world, open yourself again to gather everything in and protect us all safely in your womb!
I toast you, dark night, I toast you as victor, and this is my solace, for you make everything shorter, the day, time, life, and memory’s tribulation, in eternal oblivion!

Ever since Lessing, in his famous essay Laocoön, resolved the boundary disputes between poetry and art,5 we may take it that the upshot unanimously accepted by all aestheticians is that the difference lies in the fact that art belongs in the category of space and poetry in that of time, that art represents repose, poetry movement.
Whatever, then, is to be an object of artistic representation must have that quiet transparency in which the inner reposes in a corresponding outer.
The less this is the case, the more difficult the artist’s task becomes, until finally the difference becomes insistent and tells him that the task just isn’t his.
If we apply the distinction, not propounded here but only loosely acknowledged, to the relation between sorrow and joy, it is easy to see that joy is far easier to represent in art than sorrow.

That does not at all mean that art cannot represent sorrow, but only that there comes a point at which the essential thing is to posit an opposition between inner and outer, which makes its representation impossible for art.
This stems in turn from the very nature of sorrow.
It is of the essence of joy to reveal itself, but sorrow wants to hide, yes, sometimes even to deceive.
Joy is communicative, sociable, open-hearted, and wants to express itself; sorrow is reserved, silent, solitary, and seeks to retire into itself.
Surely not even life’s most casual observer will deny that this is correct.
There are those so constituted that under affect their blood rushes to the skin, making the inner movement outwardly visible.
Others are so constituted that the blood flows inwards, seeking the ventricles of the heart and the inner parts of the organism.
Something of the same difference is to be found in the ways joy and sorrow express themselves.
The first type of constitution described is much easier to observe than the second.
In the first you see the expression, the inner movement is outwardly visible; in the second the inner movement is intimated.
It is as though the outward pallor were the inner’s leave-taking, and thought and imagination hasten after the fugitive in its secret hiding-place.
This is especially true of the kind of sorrow I shall now consider, what may be termed reflective sorrow.
Here the outer contains at most only a hint that puts you on the track, sometimes not even that much.
This sorrow cannot be represented in art; since the equilibrium between inner and outer has been revoked, it does not lend itself to spatial specifications.
In another respect, too, it is not susceptible of representation in art, since it lacks that inner repose and is constantly in movement.
This movement, though it gives no richer content, is nevertheless the essential thing.
Like a squirrel in its cage it goes round in itself, though not so uniformly as that animal but constantly varying the combinations of sorrow’s inner elements.
What prevents reflective grief from being represented in art is that it lacks repose, that it fails to come into accord with itself, does not come to rest in any single definite expression.
As the sick person throws himself from one side to the other in pain, so does reflective sorrow toss about, looking for its object and its expression.
When sorrow finds repose, then its interior also gradually works its way outwards, becomes visible in the exterior, and so becomes an object of representation for art.

If sorrow has calm and composure, it invariably begins its movement from inside outwards; reflective sorrow moves inwards, like the blood that runs away from the surface, giving only a hint of its presence through a sudden pallor.

Reflective sorrow brings with it no characteristic outward change; from its very first moment it hastens inwards and only a reasonably careful observer suspects its vanishing; afterwards it takes great care that the exterior obtrude as little as possible.
Seeking its way thus inwards, it finds at last an enclosure, an innermost recess, where it thinks it can stay,6 and now it begins its monotonous movement.
Like the pendulum in a clock it swings back and forth and cannot find rest.
It begins always at the beginning and ponders anew, interrogates the witnesses, collates and tests their various statements, as it has already done a hundred times, yet it is never finished.
In the course of time monotony has a somewhat numbing effect.

As the monotonous drip from a roof, the steady whirl of a spinning-wheel, the monotonous sound of the measured paces of someone walking up and down on the floor above all make us numb, so in the end reflective sorrow finds relief in this movement, which becomes a necessity for it in the form of an illusion of motion.
Finally a certain equilibrium emerges.

The need for sorrow to break through, to whatever extent it may on occasion have expressed itself, ceases to exist; the exterior is calm and composed, and deep inside, in its little nook, sorrow lives like a well-guarded prisoner in an underground gaol, where it spends year after year in its monotonous movement, walking back and forth in its by-chamber, never wearying of putting sorrow’s long or short road behind it.
What gives rise to reflective sorrow can lie partly in the individual’s own subjective nature, partly in the objective sorrow itself or its occasion.

A pathologically reflective individual will transmute every sorrow into a reflective sorrow, his individual structure and organization make it impossible for him to assimilate the sorrow without further ado.
This, however, is a morbid condition of no particular interest, since any accidental happening can undergo a metamorphosis in this way and so become a reflective sorrow.
Such is always the case when the objective sorrow has not been dealt with, where it leaves a doubt behind, whatever its nature otherwise.
A great multiplicity is immediately offered to thought, the more in proportion to how much one has lived and experienced, or is disposed to employ one’s powers of discernment in such experiments.
I have no intention, however, of working through all this diversity; I shall bring out just one single aspect as this has revealed itself to my observation.
When the occasion for the sorrow is a case of deception, then the nature of the objective sorrow is such as to beget reflective sorrow in the individual.

That a deception really is such is often very hard to ascertain, and yet everything depends on this; as long as it remains disputable, sorrow will find no rest but must continue wandering back and forth in reflection.

Moreover, when this deception touches, not something external, but a person’s whole inner life, the innermost core of his life, then the probability of the reflective sorrow’s persisting becomes greater and greater.
But what, indeed, can with greater truth be called a woman’s life than her love?
So when the sorrow of an unhappy love is rooted in a deception, we have unreservedly a case of reflective sorrow, whether this persists for a lifetime or she overcomes it.
Unhappy love is certainly of itself the most profound of sorrows for a woman; but it does not follow that every unhappy love generates a reflective sorrow.

Thus when the loved one dies or perhaps she simply finds her love is unrequited, or life’s circumstances make it impossible to realize her wish, certainly there is an occasion for sorrow but not for reflective sorrow, unless the individual is already sick, in which case she falls outside the scope of our interest.

If, on the other hand, she is not sick, her sorrow will be an immediate sorrow and as such also able to become an object of representation in art, whereas on the contrary, it will be quite impossible for art to express and represent reflective sorrow or the point of it.
