chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Someone who sees you only in such an instant is very easily deceived, while someone who waits for the next instant can easily come to crow over you.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You may recall the well-known legend from Musaeus about Roland’s three pages.18 One of them acquired from the old witch they visited in the forest a thimble which made him invisible.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: With it he made his way into the chambers of the beautiful princess Urraca and declared his love for her, which made a strong impression upon her since she saw no one and so presumed it must be a fairy prince, at least, who honoured her with his love.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However, she required him to reveal himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This is where the difficulty lay: as soon as he became visible the fascination had to vanish, and yet he would have no pleasure of his love if he could not reveal himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: As it happens, I have Musaeus’s fairy-tale to hand and will transcribe a little passage from it which I would beg you to read for your own true good.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: ‘He agreed, it seemed reluctantly, and the princess’s fantasy projected the picture of the most beautiful man whom she thought with eager expectation she was about to see.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But what a contrast between the original and the ideal when all that appeared was a common, everyday visage, an ordinary person whose physiognomy betrayed neither the glance of genius nor the soul of sentiment.’ What you wish to achieve through these contacts with people, you do achieve, because since you are considerably shrewder than that page, you readily see that it cannot pay to reveal oneself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Once you have passed off an ideal picture of yourself on someone – and one has to admit you are able to appear ideal in any circumstance whatsoever – you carefully withdraw and so have then the pleasure of having fooled someone.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What you attain besides is a break in the coherence of your view, and one more point from which to start all over again.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In theoretical respects you are through with the world, the finite cannot sustain itself in your thought; in practical respects, too, you are to some extent through with it, in an aesthetic sense, that is.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Nevertheless you have no view of life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You have something resembling a view and this gives your life a certain composure which must not, though, be confused with a secure and refreshing confidence in life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You are composed only in contrast to one who still pursues the prestidigitations of pleasure, per mare pauperiem fugiens, per saxa, per ignes.19 In relation to pleasure you have an absolutely superior pride.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That is quite as it should be, for indeed you are through with the whole of finitude.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And yet you cannot give it up.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You are content compared with those who chase after contentment, but what you have become content with is absolute discontent.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: To see all the world’s glories does not concern you, for in thought you are beyond them, and if the chance were offered you would say, as always, ‘Yes, one might well devote a day to them.’ It does not trouble you that you have not become a millionaire, and if the chance of that were offered, you would no doubt reply, ‘Yes, it might have been really interesting to be that and one could well spend a month on it.’ Were it possible to offer you the love of the most beautiful girl you would still reply, ‘Yes, for half a year that would be really fine.’ I shall not join in the plaintive cry often directed at you, that you are insatiable; I will say rather: in a sense you are right, for nothing finite, even the whole world, can satisfy the soul of one who feels a need for the eternal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Were one able to offer you honour and glory, the admiration of your contemporaries – and that, after all, is your weakest point – you would reply, ‘Yes, for a short while it wouldn’t be too bad.’ You do not really want it and you would not take one step to acquire it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You would perceive that for such recognition to have any meaning your gifts would have to be so outstanding that you deserved it; here, too, your thought sees even in the highest degree of intellectual talent something transitory.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So your polemics provide you with an even more extreme expression when, in your inner resentment at the whole of life, you could wish you were the most foolish of men and yet admired and worshipped by your contemporaries as the wisest, for that would be a far more profound mockery of the whole of existence than if the genuinely most capable man were honoured as such.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So you desire nothing, wish for nothing, for the only thing you might wish for is a divining-rod which could give you everything, and then you would use it for scraping out your pipe.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Thus, you are through with life and ‘have no need to make a will since you have nothing to leave’.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But you cannot hold out on this extremity, for indeed your thought has taken everything from you but it has given you nothing in its stead.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The next instant some little triviality captivates you.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You look upon it, indeed, with all the superiority and pride your overbearing thought gives you, you despise it as a worthless toy, you are almost bored with it before you take it in your hand; but still it preoccupies you, and even if it is not the thing itself that preoccupies you – as always – you are still preoccupied with your being willing to stoop to it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In this way, once it is people you have to do with, your nature exhibits a high degree of faithlessness, for which one cannot blame you morally, however, since you are outside the category of the ethical.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Fortunately for others you participate very little, so one does not notice it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You come often to my house, and you know you are always welcome, but you know also that it never occurs to me to invite you to participate in the least thing.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I would not even take a drive in the woods with you, not because you cannot be very gay and entertaining but because your participation is always a falsehood, for if you really take pleasure one can always be certain it is not in something we others are taking pleasure in, or in the drive, but in something you have in mente; and if you do not take pleasure it is not because something unpleasant happens that puts you out of sorts, for that could also happen to the rest of us, but because the moment you climb into the carriage you have already seen the vacuity of this amusement.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I am ready to forgive you, for your mind is always too active, and it is true what you often say of yourself, that you are like a woman in confinement and when one is in that ‘condition’ it is no wonder one is a little different from others.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yet the spirit is not to be mocked, it takes its revenge on you, it fetters you in the chains of melancholy.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: My young friend, this is the way to become a Nero, if in your soul there was not an original seriousness, if there was not an innate depth in your thought, if there was no magnanimity in your soul – and if you had become Emperor of Rome.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yet you go another way.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: There now appears before you a life-view which seems the only one that can satisfy you: it is to immerse your soul in sadness and sorrow.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yet your thought is too healthy for this life-view to stand its test, for to an aesthetic sorrow of this kind existence is just as vain as it is to any other aesthetic view of life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If a person cannot sorrow more deeply, then it is true to say that the sorrow passes just as much as the joy, for everything that is merely finite passes away.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And if many find it comforting that sorrow passes, this thought seems to me just as comfortless as the thought that joy passes.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So this life-view, too, your thought annihilates, and when one has annihilated sorrow one does indeed retain joy; in place of sorrow you choose a joy which is sorrow’s changeling.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This is the joy you have now chosen, this laughter of despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You return again to life, and under this illumination existence acquires a new interest for you.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Just as you take a great delight in talking with children in a way they excellently, easily and naturally understand, though for yourself what you say means something quite different, so you delight in deceiving people with your laughter.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: When you can get people to laugh and shout for joy and be delighted with you, you triumph over the whole world; you say to yourself, ‘If only you knew what you are laughing at!’ Yet the spirit is not to be mocked, and the darkness of melancholy thickens about you, and the lightning flash of an insane wit only reveals it to you the more strongly, the more horribly.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And there is nothing that distracts you, all the world’s pleasure has no importance for you, and though you envy simple people the foolish enjoyment of life, you yourself do not pursue it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Pleasure does not tempt you; and however lamentable your condition, it is truly providential that it does not.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is my intention to praise not the pride in you that scorns pleasure but rather the moderation that holds your thought firm, for if you were tempted by pleasure you would be done for.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But the fact that it does not tempt you shows what path you must take, that you must go forward and not turn back.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: There is another false path no less dreadful, and here again I rely not on your pride but on the moderation that constantly holds you upright.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is true you are proud, and that it is better for a person to be proud than vain; it is true there is a fearful passion in your thought, that you look on it as a claim you have no intention of renouncing, that ‘you would rather consider yourself an unpaid creditor in the world than cancel it’ – and yet all human pride is but a fragile security.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Take note, then, my young friend, this life is despair; hide it from others if you will, from yourself you cannot hide it, it is despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And yet in another sense this life is not despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You are too frivolous to despair; and you are too melancholy not to come in contact with despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You are like a woman giving birth and yet you are forever putting off the moment and remain constantly in pain.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Were a woman in travail to get the idea that she might give birth to a monster, or were she to wonder what it really was she was about to give birth to, her case would be not unlike yours.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Her attempt to stay the course of nature would be unavailing, but yours indeed can succeed; for what a person gives birth to in a spiritual sense is a creative urge of the will, and that is in man’s own power.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What then is it you are afraid of?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You are not going to give birth to another human being, you will give birth only to yourself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And yet, as I know well, there is a gravity in this which perturbs the whole soul; to be conscious of oneself in one’s eternal validity is a moment more significant than everything in the world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is as though you were caught and trapped and now could never again escape, either in time or eternity; it is as though you lost yourself, as though you ceased to be; it is as though the next moment you would rue it and yet it cannot be undone.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is a grave and significant moment when one binds oneself for an eternity to an eternal power, when one receives oneself as the one whose memory no time shall efface, when in an eternal and unfailing sense one becomes aware of oneself as the person one is.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And yet, one can still let it be!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Look: here, then, is an either/or.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let me talk to you in a way I never would if another were listening, because in a sense I have no right to do so and because really I am speaking only of the future.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If this is not what you will, if you want to keep on diverting your soul with the vanities and vacuities of wit and esprit, then do so; leave your home, travel, go to Paris, give yourself up to journalism, court the smiles of voluptuous women, cool their hot blood with the breeze of your wit, let it be the proud task of your life’s activity to drive away an idle woman’s boredom or the gloomy thoughts of a flagging sensualist, forget that you were a child, that there was piety in your soul and innocence in your thought, deaden every higher voice in your breast, drowse your life away in the petty brilliance of the soirée, forget that there is an immortal spirit in you, torment your soul to the last farthing; and when wit falls silent there is water enough in the Seine and gunpowder in the general store and travelling companions for any hour of the day.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But if you cannot do that, if you will not – and you neither can nor will – then pull yourself together, stifle every rebellious thought that would presume high treason against your better nature, despise all the pettiness that would envy you your intellectual gifts and which itself desires them in order to put them to even worse use, despise the hypocritical virtue which bears life’s burdens unwillingly yet still wants to be honoured for bearing them; but do not despise life itself on that account, respect every honourable effort, every modest activity which conceals itself in humility, and above all show a little more respect for woman; believe me, it is from her that salvation comes, as certainly as depravity comes from the man.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I am a husband and to that extent partial, but it is my conviction that if ever a woman plunged humanity into depravity she has also fairly and honestly made up for it, and still does; for of a hundred men who go astray in the world ninety-nine are saved by women, one by a direct divine grace.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And since I also believe that it is man’s nature to go astray in one way or another, that this is as true of the man’s life as it is true of the woman’s that she should remain in the pure and innocent peace of immediacy, you readily perceive that in my view the woman gives ample requital for what she has done.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What then are you to do?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Another person might say: ‘Get married; then you’ll have something else to think about.’ Certainly, but the question remains whether that would be to your advantage, and whatever you think of the opposite sex, at least your thoughts are too chivalrous for you to wish to marry for that reason, and besides, if you cannot maintain yourself, you will hardly find another capable of doing that.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Or one might say, ‘Apply for some office, throw yourself into business life, that’s a distraction, and you will forget your melancholy; work, that’s the best thing.’ You might manage to reach the point where it seems as though forgotten, but forgotten it is not; now and then it will still erupt, more dreadfully than ever; it might then be able, as hitherto it has not, to take you by surprise.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Besides, whatever you think of life and its affairs, you will think too chivalrously of yourself to choose a position for that reason, for it is, after all, a kind of falsehood, just as marrying on that account.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What then are you to do?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I have only one answer: ‘Despair!’ I am a married man, my soul clings surely and unwaveringly to my wife, my children, to this life whose beauty I shall always acclaim.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So when I say ‘Despair!’ it is no overwrought youth who would have you whirled off into a maelstrom of passions, no mocking demon shouting out this comfort to the shipwrecked; I shout it to you not as a comfort, not as a state in which you are to remain, but as an action requiring all the soul’s strength and gravity and self-command, as sure as it is my conviction, my triumph over the world, that any person who has not tasted the bitterness of despair has missed the meaning of life, however beautiful and joy-filled his life has been.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You do not commit any fraud upon the world you live in, you are not lost to it, for you have conquered it, as surely as I can count myself an honourable married man even though I, too, have despaired.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: When I look at your life in this way I would call you fortunate, for truly it is of the utmost importance that a person does not look amiss at life in the moment of despair; it is just as crucial for him as for someone giving birth that things should not go wrong.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The person who despairs over something in particular runs the risk of his despair not being true and profound, of its being a disappointment, a sorrow in that particular respect.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You will not despair in that way for you have not suffered any deprivation, you still have everything.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If the despairer makes a mistake, if he believes the misfortune lies in the complex world outside him, his despair is not true and it will lead him to hate the world and not to love it; for no matter how much the world gets in your way because it seems as if it wanted to be something else than it can be for you, once you have found your own self in despair you will love it for being the world that it is.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If what brings a person to despair is some guilt and offence, a troubled conscience, he may perhaps have difficulty in regaining his good cheer.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So, despair, then, with all your soul and mind; the longer you put it off, the harder the conditions become and what is required remains the same, I shout it out to you, like the woman who offered Tarquin a collection of books for sale and, when he refused to pay the sum she asked, she burnt a third of them and demanded the same sum, and when again he refused to give the sum asked, burnt another third and demanded the same sum, until he finally gave the original sum for the remaining third.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The condition for despair in your case is therefore excellent, and yet there is an even better.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Imagine a young man, gifted like you.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let him love a girl, love her as much as himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let him once ponder in a quiet hour what he has built his life on, and on what she has built hers.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The love is something they have in common, and yet he will feel there are differences.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She, perhaps, has the gift of beauty, yet for him this is of no importance and is after all so fragile; maybe she has the joyful disposition of youth, yet for him this joy has no real meaning.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But the intellectual authority is his and he feels its strength.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He truly wants to love her, so it will not occur to him to give that to her and her humble soul will not demand it, and yet there is a difference and he will feel that it must vanish if he is truly to love her.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will then let his soul sink into despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He despairs not for his own sake but for hers, yet it is also for his own sake, for he loves her as much as himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The power of despair will then consume everything until he finds himself in his eternal validity, but then he has also found her and no knight will return happier and more joyful from the most hazardous exploits than he from this conflict with flesh and blood and the empty distinctions of the finite, for he who despairs finds the eternally human being and in that we are all equal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The foolish thought of wanting to bring about likeness by deadening his own mind or neglecting its cultivation will not occur to him; he will preserve his mental gifts but in his innermost heart he will be conscious that someone who has them is like someone who does not have them.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Or imagine a person with a deeply religious disposition who from a true and inner love of his fellow humans cast himself into the sea of despair until he found the absolute, that point where it is indifferent whether a brow is low or arches more proudly than the heavens, that point which is not indifference but the absolute validity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You have several good ideas, many odd notions, a mass of silly ones; keep them all.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I do not insist, but there is one idea I would beg you to hold on to, an idea which assures me that my own spirit is in kinship with yours.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You have often said you would rather be anything else in the world than a poet since a poet-existence is, as a rule, a human sacrifice.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I, for my part, would by no means deny there have been poets who have gained their selves before they began to write; on the other hand, it is also certain that a poet-existence as such lies in the obscurity that results from despair’s not being carried through, from the soul’s constantly shivering in despair and the spirit’s being unable to gain its true transparency.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The poetic ideal is always an untrue ideal, for the true ideal is always what is actual.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So when the spirit is not allowed to vault up into its own eternal world it remains en route and revels in the pictures reflected in the clouds and weeps over their transience.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A poet-existence is therefore, as such, an unhappy existence, it is higher than the finite and yet not the infinite.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The poet sees the ideals but he has to flee the world in order to take pleasure in them; he cannot carry these divine images within him in the midst of life’s confusion, cannot quietly proceed on his way unaffected by the caricature appearing all around him, not to speak of having the strength to attire himself in those images.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The poet’s life is, therefore, often the object of a petty sympathy on the part of those who think themselves safe because they have remained in the finite.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You once said in a moment of despondency that no doubt there were already people who had privately made up their accounts with you and were willing to settle on the following condition: that you were recognized as a bright fellow, in return you sank from sight and did not become a useful member of society.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yes, there undeniably exists in the world a pettiness of this kind, which will triumph in this way over everything that protrudes just an inch.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But do not let it disturb you, do not defy them, do not scorn them; I would say here, as you usually do, ‘It isn’t worth the trouble.’ But if you do not want to be a poet there is no other way for you than the one I have shown you: Despair!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So then choose despair, since despair is itself a choice, for one can doubt without choosing to, but despair one cannot without choosing to do so.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And when one despairs one chooses again, and what then does one choose?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One chooses oneself, not in one’s immediacy, not as this contingent individual, one chooses oneself in one’s eternal validity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I shall endeavour to cast a little more light on this point in your connection.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In recent philosophy there has been more than enough talk about speculation beginning with doubt; on the other hand, so far as I have been able occasionally to occupy myself with questions of that kind, I have looked in vain for information on how doubt differs from despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here I shall try to clarify that distinction, in the hope that it will contribute to orienting you and facing you in the right direction.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I am far from presuming any real philosophical competence, I do not have your virtuosity in playing with categories, but what in the deepest sense is the meaning of life, that after all must surely be comprehensible to a more simple-minded person.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Doubt is a despair of thought, despair is a doubt of the personality.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That is why I keep such a tight hold on the category of choice, that being my watchword, the nerve of my life-view, and that is something I indeed have even if I make no claim at all to a system.20 Doubt is the inner movement in thought itself, and in my doubt I conduct myself as impersonally as possible.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Assume now that, doubt having been applied, thought finds the absolute and rests in it; it rests in it not as the result of a choice but following the same necessity according to which it doubted; for doubt itself belongs to the category of necessity, and rest likewise.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is the sublime aspect of doubt, the reason why doubt has so often been praised and extolled by people who scarcely understood what they were saying.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But this fact, that it belongs to the category of necessity, shows that it is not the whole personality that is in motion.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So there is something very true in a person’s saying, ‘I’d like to believe it, but I can’t; I have to doubt.’ That is also why one often sees how a doubter can still possess something positive in himself which lives apart from all communication through thought, that he can be a highly conscientious person who has no doubts whatever about the validity of duty and about the maxim for his action, no doubts whatever about a multitude of sympathetic feelings and moods.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: On the other hand, especially in our own time, one sees people who have despair in their hearts but have still conquered doubt.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This has particularly struck me in considering certain of Germany’s philosophers.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Their thought is composed, the objective logical thought is brought to rest in its corresponding objectivity, and yet they are in despair even though they distract themselves with objective thinking, for there are many ways a person can distract himself and scarcely any sedative is more effective than abstract thinking, since there it is a matter of conducting oneself as impersonally as possible.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Doubt and despair therefore belong to two quite different spheres, different sides of the soul are set in motion.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Still, I am not at all content with this, because doubt and despair would then rank equally and that is not the case.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Despair is a far deeper and more complete expression, its movement far more comprehensive than doubt’s.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Precisely, despair is an expression of the whole personality, doubt only of thought.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The reputed objectivity of doubt, what makes it so distinguished, is precisely an expression of its incompleteness.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Doubt, therefore, lies in difference, despair in the absolute.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It requires talent to doubt, it requires no talent at all to despair; but talent as such is difference and what needs talent to make it effectual can never be the absolute, for it is only for the absolute that the absolute can be absolute as such.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The lowliest, least talented person can despair, a young girl who is least of all a thinker can despair, while it is easy for anyone to sense the foolishness of saying of these that they are doubters.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The reason why a person’s doubt can be assuaged and he can still be in despair, and that this can go on, is that he does not in a deeper sense will despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In general, one cannot despair at all unless one wants to, but in order truly to despair one must truly want to, but when one truly wills despair one is truly beyond it; when one has truly chosen despair one has truly chosen what despair chooses, namely oneself in one’s eternal validity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is only in despair that the personality is assuaged, though not with necessity, for I never despair necessarily, but with freedom, and only in despair is the absolute attained.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I think in this respect our age will make progress, so far as I am entitled to an opinion about our age – that is, seeing I know it only from reading newspapers and the occasional pamphlet, or from our conversations.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The time won’t be far off when, perhaps at some cost, we will learn that the true point of departure for finding the absolute is not doubt but despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But I return to my category, I am not a logician, I have only one such but I assure you it is the choice of both my heart and my mind, my soul’s desire and my salvation – I return to the significance of choice.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In choosing absolutely, then, I choose despair, and in despair I choose the absolute, for I myself am the absolute, I posit the absolute and am myself the absolute.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But, as amounts to exactly the same, I must say: I choose the absolute which chooses me, I posit the absolute which posits me.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For unless I bear in mind that this second expression is just as absolute, my category of choice is false; for that category is precisely the identity of both.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What I choose I do not posit, for if it were not posited I could not choose it, and yet if it were not posited through my choosing it I would not choose it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is, for if it was not I could not choose it; it is not, for it only comes to be by my choosing it, otherwise my choice would be illusory.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But what, then, do I choose?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This thing or that?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: No, I choose absolutely, and I choose absolutely precisely through having chosen not to choose this thing or that.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I choose the absolute, and what is the absolute?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is myself in my eternal validity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Anything other than myself I cannot choose as the absolute, for if I choose something else I choose it as something finite, and therefore do not choose it absolutely.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Even the Jew who chose God did not choose absolutely, for although he chose the absolute he did not choose it absolutely, and so it ceased to be the absolute and became something finite.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But what, then, is this self of mine?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If it is to be a matter of a first glance, a first shot at a definition, my answer is: it is the most abstract thing of all which yet, at the same time, is the most concrete thing of all – it is freedom.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let me here make a small psychological observation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One often hears people giving vent to their discontent by complaining of life, one often hears them making wishes.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Imagine such a poor devil, but let us hop over wishes that do not throw light on anything here because they belong entirely to the contingent.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He wishes, ‘If only I had that man’s mind, or his talents,’ etc.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yes, at the farthest extreme, ‘If only I had that man’s firmness.’ One hears wishes like this frequently enough, but have you ever heard a person seriously wish that he could become someone else?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So far is that from being so, that it is precisely typical of what are called unfortunates that it is they who cling most tightly to themselves, that despite all their sufferings they would not for all the world want to be someone else; which has its reason in the fact that such individuals are very near the truth and have a sense of the eternal validity of personal existence, not in its blessings but in its torment, even if they have kept to themselves this perfectly abstract expression of joy in their eternal validity which says they would rather be themselves than anyone else.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: As for the man with many wishes, he still thinks of always remaining himself though everything were changed.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So there is something in him that is absolute in relation to everything else, something whereby he is the one he is, even if the change he obtains through his wish were the greatest possible.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That he is labouring under a misunderstanding I shall show later; here I want merely to find the most abstract expression for this ‘self’ which makes him what he is.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And that is nothing else than freedom.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Really it would be possible in this way to offer a highly plausible proof of the eternal validity of personal existence; yes, even a suicide does not really want to do away with his self; he, too, has a wish, he wishes he had another form of his self, and there could well be a suicide, therefore, who was convinced in the highest degree of the immortality of the soul but whose whole being was so confused that he thought to find in this way the absolute form of his spirit.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But the reason why it can seem to an individual that he could constantly change yet remain the same, as if his inmost being were an algebraic entity that could stand for whatever it might be, is to be found in the fact that he has the wrong attitude; he has not chosen himself, he has no conception of doing so, and yet even in his lack of understanding there is an acknowledgement of the eternal validity of personal existence.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For someone with the right attitude, on the other hand, things go differently.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He chooses himself, not in a finite sense, for then this ‘self’ would be something finite along with other finite things, but in an absolute sense.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And still he chooses himself and not another.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This self he thus chooses is infinitely concrete, for it is himself, and yet it is absolutely different from his former self, for he has chosen it absolutely.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This self did not exist previously, for it came into existence through the choice, and yet it has been in existence, for it was indeed ‘he himself’.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The choice here makes the two dialectical movements at once: what is chosen does not exist and comes into existence through the choice, and what is chosen exists, otherwise it would not be a choice.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For if the thing I chose did not exist but became absolute through the choice itself, I would not have chosen, I would have created.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But I do not create myself, I choose myself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Therefore while nature has been created out of nothing, while I myself qua my immediate personal existence have been created out of nothing, as free spirit I am born of the principle of contradiction, or born by virtue of the fact that I chose myself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He now discovers that the self he chooses contains an infinite multiplicity inasmuch as it has a history, a history in which he acknowledges identity with himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This is history of a different sort, for in this history he stands in relation to other individuals of the race and to the race as a whole, and in this history there is something painful, yet he is only the one he is, with this history.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Therefore it needs courage to choose oneself, for just when he seems to be becoming most isolated, he is entering more deeply than ever into the roots through which he is linked with the whole.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It alarms him, and yet that is how it has to be, for when he awakens to the passion of freedom – and that has been awakened in the choice, just as the choice presupposes it – he chooses himself and fights to possess it as though for his blessedness, and it is his blessedness.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He can let go of none of this, not the most painful things, not the most grievous, and yet the expression of this fight, of this acquiring, is – repentance.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He repents himself back into himself, back into the family, back into the race, until he finds himself in God.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Only on these terms can he choose himself and he wants no others, for only thus can he absolutely choose himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What, after all, is a human being without love?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yet there are many kinds of love.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I love a father in a different way from a mother, my wife in still another way, and every different love has its different expression, but there is also a love wherewith I love God, and there is only one expression for this in language: repentance.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If I do not love Him thus I do not love Him absolutely, not from my inmost being; any other love for the absolute is a misunderstanding since – to take what people usually praise so highly and I myself have respect for – when thinking clings to the absolute with all its love it is not the absolute I love, I do not love absolutely since I love necessarily; as soon as I love freely and love God, I repent.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And were there no other reason for repentance being the expression of my love of God, there is this reason: that he loved me first.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And yet this is an incomplete account, for it is only if I choose myself as guilty that I choose myself absolutely, if ever my choosing myself absolutely is not to be identical with creating myself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And if the sins of the father were inherited by the son, this too he repents, for only in this way can he choose himself, choose himself absolutely.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And if the tears are just about to efface him completely, he still keeps on repenting, for only thus does he choose himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is as though his self is outside him and is to be taken possession of, and the repentance is his love of it, because he chooses it absolutely, from the hand of the eternal God.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What I have stated here is no rostrum-wisdom, it is something every person who wants to can propound, and which every person can want to when he will.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I have not learnt it in the auditorium, I have learnt it in the living-room, or in the nursery if you will, for when I see my little son running across the floor, so joyful, so happy, I think, ‘Who knows, perhaps I’ve had a very damaging influence on him?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: God knows I take all possible care of him, but that thought doesn’t put me at ease.’ Then I say to myself, ‘There’ll come a moment in his life when his spirit too will be matured in the instant of choice, then he will choose himself, then he will also repent whatever guilt of mine may rest upon him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And there’s something pleasing about a son’s repenting his father’s sins, though he won’t do it on my account but because it is only in this way that he can choose himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So let things go as they will; often what one considers best has the most damaging consequences for a person, but all this is nothing after all.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I can do a lot for him, that’s what I’ll strive for, but the highest he can only do for himself.’ You see why people have such difficulty in choosing themselves: here absolute isolation is identical with the deepest continuity, and as long as one has not chosen oneself it is as if there was a possibility of becoming something different, in one way or another.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here, then, you have my humblest opinion on what it is to choose and to repent.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is unseemly to love a young girl as though she were one’s mother, or one’s mother as though she were a young girl.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Every love has its peculiarity; love of God has its absolute peculiarity, its expression is repentance.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A theologian will be able to base a host of reflections on this point.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: These I shall not go into further since I am only a layman.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I shall try only to throw light on the foregoing with the comment that it is in Christianity that repentance first found its true expression.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The pious Jew felt the sins of the fathers weigh upon him, yet he did not feel it nearly as deeply as the Christian, because the pious Jew could not repent it, for he could not choose himself absolutely.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The guilt of the fathers weighed upon him, brooded over him, he sank beneath this burden, he sighed, but he could not lift it; only the one who chooses himself absolutely can do that, through repentance.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The greater the freedom the greater the guilt, and that is the secret of blessedness, and if not cowardice, it is at least faintheartedness not to want to repent the sins of the fathers; if not to be despised, it is at least petty and devoid of magnanimity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So then the choice of despair is ‘my self’, for although when I despair I despair over myself as over all else, the self I despair over is a finitude as every other finite thing, while the self I choose is the absolute self or my self according to its absolute validity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That being so, you will again see why I kept on saying in the above that the either/or I proposed between living aesthetically and ethically is not a perfect dilemma, because there is really only one option.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Through choosing it I do not really choose between good and evil, I choose the good, but by virtue of choosing the good I choose the option between good and evil.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The original choice is constantly present in every subsequent choice.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So despair, then, and your frivolity shall never more cause you to roam like an inconstant spirit, like a ghost among the ruins of a world which is yet lost to you; despair, and your spirit shall never more sigh in melancholy, for the world shall become beautiful and joyous to you once more, though you now look at it with different eyes, and your spirit, now liberated, shall vault up into the world of freedom.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here I could break off, for I have now brought you to the point I wished.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For this, should you yourself wish it, is where you are.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: My aim was for you to tear yourself away from the illusions of the aesthetic, and from a dream of half despair, in order to awaken to the earnest of spirit.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However, I have no intention of doing that, since I want now to give you, from this vantage-point, a way of looking at life, an ethical life-view.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is only a frugal offering, partly because my talents are in no way commensurate to the task, partly because frugality is a prime characteristic of everything ethical, a characteristic which can be arresting enough for someone coming from the abundance of the aesthetic.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here what matters is nil ad ostentationem, omnia ad conscientiam.21 Breaking off at this point might also seem questionable for another reason: one might easily get the impression that I had ended up in a sort of quietism,22 where the personality necessarily comes to rest as thought does in the absolute.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What then would be the good of having gained oneself, what would be the good of getting a sword which could conquer the whole world if one did nothing with it but thrust it into the scabbard?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But before going on to present such an ethical view of life in more detail, I will indicate in a few words the danger that lies before one in the moment of despair, the reef one can run aground on and be totally shipwrecked.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The Scriptures say, ‘What is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world and suffer harm to his own soul?’23  But the expression ‘suffer harm to his own soul’ is an ethical one, and the person who thinks he has an ethical life-view must also presume to be able to interpret it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One hears the phrase frequently, yet any person who wants to understand it must have felt deep commotions in his soul; yes, he must have despaired, for what are really set before us here are the motions of despair: on the one hand the whole world, on the other one’s own soul.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You will readily perceive that, if one pursues this phrase, one arrives at the same abstract definition of ‘soul’ which, in our psychological consideration of the desire to become another, though without becoming another, we reached earlier as the definition of ‘self’.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For when I can gain the whole world yet suffer harm to my soul, the phrase ‘whole world’ must also include all the finitudes I possess in virtue of my immediacy.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: My soul then proves impervious to these.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: When I can lose the whole world without suffering harm to my soul, the phrase ‘the whole world’ again includes all those determinations of finitude that are mine in virtue of my immediacy, and yet my soul remains unharmed; it is accordingly impervious to them.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I can lose my wealth, my esteem in the eyes of others, my mental powers, and still not suffer harm to my soul.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I can gain all these and still suffer harm.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What then is my soul, what is this inmost being of mine that can remain unaffected by this loss and suffer harm with this gain?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This movement is manifest to the despairer, it is no rhetorical phrase but the only adequate one when, on the one hand, he sees the whole world and, on the other, himself, his soul.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In the moment of despair the distinction makes itself apparent, and now it is a matter of how he despairs, for, as I explained above in connection with every aesthetic view of life, it is despair to gain the whole world and gain it in such a way that one suffers harm to one’s soul; and yet it is my heartfelt conviction that it is a man’s true salvation to despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here, again, we have the importance of willing one’s own despair, willing it in an infinite sense, in an absolute sense, for such willing is identical with absolute self-surrender.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If, on the other hand, I will my despair in a finite sense I suffer harm to my soul, for then my inmost being does not attain its breakthrough in despair; on the contrary, it isolates itself, it is hardened, so that finite despair is a hardening, absolute despair an infinitization.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If in my despair I gain the whole world, I suffer harm to my soul by making myself finite, I have my life in that world; when I despair over losing the whole world I suffer harm to my soul, for I make it finite in exactly the same way, since here again I see my soul as posited with finitude.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Every finite despair is a choice of the finite, for I choose it as much when I lose it as when I gain it; for what lies in my power is not whether I gain it, but my choosing it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Finite despair is therefore an unfree despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Really despair is not the aim, but finitude, yet that is despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A person can now hold out at this point, and as long as he stays there I cannot really bring myself to say to him that he has suffered harm to his soul.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He stands at a highly dangerous point.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: At every moment there is the possibility of its happening.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The despair is there but it has not yet attacked his inmost being.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Only when in a finite sense he hardens himself in the despair, only then does he suffer harm to his soul.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: His soul is as if anaesthetized in despair, and only when, on coming round, he chooses a finite way out of his despair, only then does he suffer harm to his soul; he has isolated himself, his rational soul is stifled and he is transformed into a beast of prey that shuns no means since everything for him is self-defence.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: There lies a dreadful anxiety in this thought that a person has suffered harm to his soul, yet everyone who has despaired will have had a presentiment of this false path, this perdition.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That a person can suffer harm to his soul in this way is certain; whether it is actually the case with a particular person is impossible to tell, and no one ventures here to judge another.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A man’s life may look strange and one may be tempted to believe it of him, yet he himself may have quite a different interpretation which assures him of the opposite; on the other hand, a person may have suffered harm to his soul without anyone suspecting it, for this harm lies not on the outside but in the person’s inmost being.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is like the rot in the core of the fruit: while the outside can look appetizing, it gives no hint of the inner hollowness.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So when you choose yourself absolutely you easily find out that this self is not an abstraction or a tautology; at the most it may seem so in the moment of orientation when one separates to the point of finding the most abstract expression of this self, but it is still just an illusion that it is altogether abstract and without content, for after all it is not the consciousness of freedom in general, since that is a determination of thought; it is the product of a choice and is the consciouness of this determinate free being which is himself and no other.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This self contains a rich concretion, a multitude of determinate qualities, of characteristics; it is, in short, the whole aesthetic self which is chosen ethically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Therefore the more you become absorbed in yourself, the greater sense you will have of the significance even of the insignificant, not in a finite but in an infinite sense, because it is through you that it is posited, and when one chooses oneself in an ethical sense it is not just a reflection upon oneself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: To characterize this act, one might recall the word of the Scriptures about giving account of every idle word that men shall speak.24 For when the passion of freedom is awakened, freedom is jealous of itself and by no means allows it to remain thus indeterminate as between what does and does not belong to it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So while in the first instant of choice the person proceeds apparently as naked as the child from its mother’s womb, the next instant it is concrete in itself, and it is only by an arbitrary abstraction that someone can remain at that point.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He becomes himself – quite the same as he was before, down to the least significant peculiarity – and yet he becomes another, for the choice permeates everything and transforms it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Thus is his finite personality now made infinite in the choice in which he infinitely chooses himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So now he owns himself as posited by himself, that is, as chosen by himself, as free; but when he owns himself in this way, an absolute difference appears, that between good and evil.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So long as he has not chosen himself this difference remains latent.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: How in general does the difference between good and evil emerge?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Can we think it – that is, is it something for thought?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: No.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here the point comes up again that I touched on above, how philosophy could seem actually to have abolished the principle of contradiction, the reason being that it has not yet reached it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Whenever I think, my relation to what it is I am thinking is one of necessity, but that is exactly why the difference between good and evil does not arise.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Think anything you like, think the most abstract categories of all, think the most concrete, you never think in the category of good and evil; think the whole of history and you think the necessary movement of the Idea, but you never think in the category of good and evil.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You always think relative differences, never the absolute difference.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Philosophy, so far as I can judge, may well be justified in claiming it cannot think an absolute contradiction, but it by no means follows that the latter does not exist.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In thinking, I make myself infinite, but not absolutely, since I disappear into the absolute; it is only when I choose myself absolutely that I make myself infinite absolutely, for I myself am the absolute, for it is only myself that I can choose absolutely, and this absolute choice of myself is my freedom; only when I have absolutely chosen myself have I posited an absolute difference, namely that between good and evil.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In order to abolish the element of self-determination in thought, philosophy says, ‘The absolute is by virtue of my thinking it.’ But since philosophy itself sees that this implies free thought (not necessary thought, which is the one it usually acclaims), it replaces this expression with another, namely that my thought of the absolute is the ‘absolute’s self-thinking’ in me.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This expression is not at all identical with the previous one, but on the other hand it is entirely appropriate.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For here my thought is an element in the absolute, that is where the necessity of my thought lies, that is where the necessity with which I think the absolute lies.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Things are different with the good.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The good is by virtue of my willing it, and otherwise it has no existence.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This is the expression of freedom; similarly with evil, it is only by virtue of my willing it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This is in no way to belittle the categories of good and evil or to reduce them to merely subjective determinations.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: On the contrary, it is to assert the absolute validity of these categories.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The good is the in-and-for-itself posited by the in-and-for-itself, and that is freedom.25 My use of the expression ‘choosing oneself absolutely’ may seem questionable, for it might be taken to imply that I chose good and evil equally absolutely, and that both good and evil belonged to me equally essentially.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: To prevent this misunderstanding I used the expression ‘repenting myself out of the whole of existence’.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For repentance is the expression of the fact that evil is an essential part of me, and at the same time the expression of the fact that it is not essentially a part of me.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If evil were not an essential part of me I could not choose it, but if there were something in me that I could not choose absolutely, then there would be no question of my choosing myself absolutely; I would not be the absolute myself, but only a product.
