chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here I will break off these reflections in order to show how an ethical life-view looks at the person and life and its meaning.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For form’s sake I return to some observations made earlier about the relation between the aesthetic and the ethical.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: We said that every aesthetic life-view was despair; this was because it was built upon what may or may not be.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That is not the case with the ethical life-view, for this builds life upon what has being as its essential property.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The aesthetic, we said, is that in which a person is immediately what he is; the ethical is that whereby a person becomes what he becomes.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This in no way implies that someone who lives aesthetically does not develop, but he develops with necessity, not with freedom; there occurs no metamorphosis in his case, no infinite movement whereby he arrives at the point from which he becomes what he becomes.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: When an individual considers himself aesthetically, he becomes conscious of this self of his as a multiple concretion inwardly determined in many ways, but in spite of all the inner diversity it is all still his nature, everything has just as much right to come to light, is just as entitled to demand satisfaction.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: His soul is like soil from which there spring all kinds of herbs, all equally entitled to thrive; it is in this diversity that his self lies, and he has no self higher than this.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Now, if he has what you so often speak of, namely aesthetic seriousness and a little worldly wisdom, he will see that it is impossible for everything to thrive equally.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So he will choose, and what decides his choice is a more-or-less, which is a relative difference.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let us now suppose someone were able to live without coming in contact with the ethical; he would then be able to say, ‘I have it in me to be a Don Juan, a Faust, a robber chief; I shall now cultivate this trait since aesthetic seriousness demands that I become something definite, that I let the seedling planted in me develop fully.’ Aesthetically, that way of looking at personality and its development would be perfectly proper.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: From this you see what an aesthetic development means: it is a development like that of the plant, and although the individual becomes something, what it becomes is what it is immediately.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For someone who regards personhood ethically there is, from the very first, an absolute difference, namely that between good and evil, and if he finds more evil than good, that still does not mean that evil is what has to come to the fore, but that evil is to be suppressed and the good allowed to come to the fore.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So when the individual develops ethically, he comes to be what he becomes; for even when he gives rein to the aesthetic in him (which for him means something else than for the one who lives merely aesthetically), it has nevertheless been removed from its throne.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It takes much ethical courage not to be distinguished by difference but to be content with the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Everyone who lives merely aesthetically  has a secret dread of despairing, for he knows very well that what despair brings out is the universal, and at the same time he knows that his life is based on difference.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The higher the individual stands, the more differences he has done away with or despaired over, but he always retains one difference which he will not do away with, on which his life is based.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is curious to see the admirable assurance with which even the most simple-minded discover what one might call their aesthetic difference, however insignificant that may be, and one of life’s miseries is the foolish controversy carried on about which difference is more significant than another.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Aesthetic minds also express their aversion to despair by saying it is a break.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This expression is quite appropriate so far as one supposes life’s development to consist of a necessary unfolding of the immediate.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If that is not the case, then despair is no break but a transfiguration.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Only a person despairing over something in particular suffers a break, but that is just because he does not despair to the full.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Aesthetes are also afraid that life will lose the diverting multiplicity it has so long as one looks at it as though every single individual lived under aesthetic categories.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Once again, this is a misunderstanding, no doubt fostered by a number of rigoristic theories.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In despair nothing is destroyed, all a person’s aesthetic qualities remain, it is just that they become ancillary and are preserved for that very reason.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yes, it is indeed true that one does not live in the aesthetic as one did, but it by no means follows that one loses it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It may be true that one uses it otherwise, but it does not follow that it has gone away.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: All the ethicist does is to carry to its conclusion the doubt which the higher aesthete had already set in motion but which he broke off arbitrarily; for, however great his difference, it is still only relative.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And when the aesthetician himself admits that the difference which gives his life meaning is also transitory, but adds that it is still always best to enjoy it as long as one has it, this is really a cowardice in love with a certain kind of enjoyment of ease, under not too high a ceiling, and is unworthy of a human being.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is as though someone were to rejoice in some relationship based on a misunderstanding which, sooner or later, would have to come into the open, and lacked the courage to be cognizant of this or to admit it, but rejoiced in the relationship as long as possible.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However, this is not the case with you; you are like someone who has admitted the misunderstanding, broken off the relationship, but then wants to be forever taking leave of it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The aesthetic view also considers personal existence in its relation to the environment, and the expression of this in its impact on the individual is pleasure.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But the aesthetic expression of pleasure in its relation to personal existence is mood.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For the person is present in the mood but present only in a shadowy way.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A person living aesthetically tries as much as possible to be completely taken up in the mood; he tries to hide himself totally within it, so that there is nothing in him which cannot be bent into conformity with it, for any residue always has a disturbing effect, it is an element of continuity that tries to hold him back.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The more his personal being merges into mood, the more the individual is in the moment, and again this is the most adequate expression of aesthetic existence: it is in the moment.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Hence the huge oscillations to which the person who lives aesthetically is exposed.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A person living ethically also knows mood, but for him it is not the most important thing; because he has chosen himself infinitely he sees the mood beneath him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The remainder that will not fit into the mood is exactly that continuity which is for him what is most important.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Someone living ethically has  a memory of his life, a person living aesthetically certainly has not.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Someone living ethically does not do away with mood, he sizes it up for an instant, but this instant saves him from living in the moment, this instant gives him mastery over desire, for the art of mastering desire consists not so much in doing away with it, or giving it up altogether, as in determining the instant.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Take any pleasure you like, its secret, its strength, consists in its being contained absolutely in the moment.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: True, one often hears people saying that the only way is to abstain altogether.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That is a very mistaken way and only succeeds for a while.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Take someone who has become addicted to gambling.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Desire is aroused with all its passion, it is as though his life were at stake if the desire is not satisfied.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If he can say to himself, ‘Not just now; in an hour’s time’, he is cured.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This hour is the continuity that saves him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For someone living aesthetically the mood is always eccentric, because he has his centre at the periphery.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Personal being has its centre in itself, and someone who does not have himself is eccentric.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Someone living ethically, however, has his mood centralized, he is not inside the mood, he is not the mood itself, he has mood and has the mood in him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What he works for is continuity and that is always master over mood.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: His life does not lack mood, indeed it has a total mood, but it is acquired; it is what one could call equability, but this is no aesthetic mood, and no one has it by nature or immediately.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But he who has now infinitely chosen himself – can he say, ‘Now I own myself, I ask nothing more, and to all the world’s vicissitudes I oppose the proud thought: I am the one I am’?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: By no means!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If anyone were to express themselves in that way one could easily see they had gone astray.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The basic mistake would also lie in his not having chosen himself in the strictest sense; choose himself he may have done, but he has done it from outside himself; he had understood quite abstractly what it was to choose and had failed to grasp himself in his concretion; he had not so chosen himself that, in the choice, he came to be within himself, had not clothed himself in himself; he had chosen himself in respect of his necessity, not of his freedom; he had taken the ethical option in vain, aesthetically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The more truly meaningful the outcome that emerges, the more dangerous are the false paths, and here too, accordingly, there appears a dreadful false path.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Once the individual has grasped himself in his eternal validity, this overwhelms him with all its fullness.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The temporal vanishes from sight.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: At first it fills him with an indescribable bliss and gives him a sense of absolute security.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If, then, it is this that he begins to gaze one-sidedly upon, the temporal presses its claims.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: They are rejected.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What the temporal has to offer, the more-or-less that presents itself here, is for him so very unimportant compared with what he owns eternally.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Everything stops short for him, it is as though he had reached eternity before his time.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He becomes lost in contemplation, he gazes at himself, but his gazing cannot fill up the time.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It then seems to him that time, the temporal, is his ruin, he demands a perfect form of life, and here again appears a fatigue similar to the languor attending pleasure.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This apathy can rest so broodingly over a person that suicide seems the only way out.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: No power can wrest his self from him, the only power is time, yet neither can this wrest his self from him, but checks and delays him, it detains the spiritual embrace in which he grasps himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He has not chosen himself; like Narcissus, he has fallen in love with himself.26 It is certainly not seldom such a situation has ended in suicide.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The mistake lies in the fact that he has not chosen in the right way, not just in the sense that he has been insensible of his errors, but he has seen himself in the category of necessity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Himself, this person with all these multiple characteristics, he has seen as part of the way of the world, he has seen his self over against the eternal power, whose fire has permeated it but without consuming it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But he has not seen himself in his freedom, has not chosen himself in that.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If he does that, the very moment he chooses himself he is in motion; however concrete his self is, he has still chosen himself in respect of his possibility, he has purchased his freedom in order to stay in it, but he can only stay in his freedom by constantly realizing it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is for that reason he has chosen himself, by virtue of that fact he is active.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here might be the place to say a few words about a life-view which you find most agreeable, particularly as teacher, sometimes also as practitioner.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What it amounts to is nothing less than that the real meaning of life, after all, is sorrow, and being the unhappiest is the happiest thing of all.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: At first glance this does not look like an aesthetic view of life, for its slogan can scarcely be pleasure.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Neither, however, is it ethical, but it lies at the dangerous transition between the aesthetic and the ethical, where the soul is so easily seduced by one or another version of the theory of predestination.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You proclaim a number of false doctrines, and this is about the worst, but you know also it is the one most fitted for sneaking your way in upon people and drawing them to you.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You can be as heartless as any, you can joke about everything, even about man’s pain.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You are not unaware that young people are tempted by this, yet this conduct puts you at some distance from them, for such behaviour repels as much as it attracts.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If it is a young woman you want to deceive in this way, you cannot but notice that a womanly soul has too much depth to be captivated permanently by such things; yes, even if you engaged her attention for a moment, she will soon end up wearying of it and forming something close to an aversion to you because her soul is in no need of such titillation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The method is then changed; in isolated enigmatic outbursts, which only she can understand, you let it be hinted that it can all be explained by a remote melancholy.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You open yourself only to her, but with such caution that she really never gets to know anything more; you leave it to her imagination to depict the details of the profound sadness you hide within you.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Shrewd, one cannot deny you are that, and it is true what a young girl said about you, that probably you will end up a Jesuit.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The more subtly you can pass them the thread that leads deeper and deeper into the secrets of sadness, the more joyful you are, the more sure of drawing them to you.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You do not make long speeches, you do not protest your pain in firm handclasps, or by ‘gazing romantically into the romantic eyes of a kindred soul’; you are too smart for that.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You avoid witnesses, and only occasionally let yourself be taken by surprise.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: At a certain age, there is no more dangerous poison to a young girl than sadness; you know that, and this knowledge may, like any other, be all very well in itself; your use of it, on the other hand, is not something I shall praise.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is part of the whole development in modern times that people are more disposed to feel sorrow than joy.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is considered a higher view of life, and so it is, inasmuch as it is natural to want to be joyful, and unnatural to sorrow.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: On top of that there is the fact that being joyful does after all impose a certain obligation on the individual to be thankful, even if his thoughts are too confused for him to know just whom he should thank; sorrow absolves one from that and vanity is then better satisfied.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Besides, our age has experienced the vanity of life in so many ways that it does not believe in joy, and as it still has to have something to believe in, it believes in sorrow.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Joy passes away, it says, but sorrow lasts and anyone who bases his view of life on it builds on a solid foundation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If we ask now more explicitly what sort of sorrow it is you are talking about, you are shrewd enough to evade ethical sorrow.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is not repentance you mean; no, it is aesthetic sorrow, reflected sorrow in particular.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is based not on guilt but on misfortune, on fate, on a sad disposition, the influence of others, etc.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is something with which you are all too familiar from novels.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: When you read it there you laugh at it, if you hear others talk of it you mock them; but when you yourself discourse on it, it makes sense and there is truth in it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Now although the view that takes sorrow to be the meaning of life can seem itself to be sorrowful enough, I cannot neglect to show you, from an angle you perhaps would not expect, that it offers no comfort.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Someone who says that sorrow is the meaning of life has joy outside him in the same way that someone who wants to be joyful has sorrow outside him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Joy may take him by surprise in exactly the same way that sorrow can take the other.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So his life-view is tied to a condition which is not under his control, for it is really just as little under someone’s control to refrain from joy as to refrain from sorrow.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But any life-view with a condition outside it is despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And so wanting to sorrow is despair in exactly the same sense as wanting to seek joy, since it is always despair to have one’s life centred in something whose nature it is to cease to be.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The deeper the source of sorrow, the more it can seem that one might preserve it all one’s life, as if there was indeed nothing one need do to make it so, it will stay as a matter of course.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If it is some particular event, that will prove very difficult.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You yourself are fully aware of that, and so when you want to pronounce on the meaning of sorrow for the whole of life you think mainly of unhappy characters and tragic heroes.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is a feature of the entire spiritual disposition of the unhappy character that he is unable to be happy or joyful, a fate broods over him, and similarly over the tragic hero.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So here you are perfectly justified in saying that sorrow is the meaning of life; and this has brought us to plain fatalism, which always has something seductive about it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here also you encounter your allegation which amounts neither more nor less to the claim that you yourself are the unhappiest man.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And yet it is undeniable that this thought is the proudest and most defiant that can arise in a man’s brain.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let me answer you as you deserve.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: First of all, you do not sorrow.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This you know full well, for it is your favourite saying that the unhappiest is the happiest.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But this is a falsification more appalling than any other; it is a falsification which turns against the eternal power that governs the world, it is a rebellion against God, like wanting to laugh when you should weep; and yet there is a despair that is capable of it, there is a defiance that pits itself against God.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But that is also treason against the human race.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: True, you too distinguish between sorrows, but you think there is a difference so great as to allow a kind that it is impossible to bear.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But if such a sorrow exists, it is not for you to decide which it is, one difference is as good as another, and you have betrayed man’s deepest and most sacred right or grace.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is treason against what is great, a mean envy, for what it comes down to is that the great men have not been subjected to the most dangerous trials, have slipped easily into their honours, and that they would also have succumbed had the superhuman temptation you speak of come their way.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And is this the way you intend to honour what is great, by belittling it?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You mean to bear witness to it by denying it?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And do not misunderstand me now.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I am not the kind that thinks one should not sorrow, I despise that petty common sense, and if this is all the choice there is, then I choose sorrow.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: No, I am aware that to sorrow is beautiful, and that there is mettle in tears; but I also know that one shall not sorrow as one who has not hope.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: There is an absolute opposition between us that can never be abolished.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I cannot live in aesthetic categories, I feel what I hold most sacred is destroyed; I need a higher expression and the ethical gives me that.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And this is where sorrow first acquires its true and profound meaning.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Do not be shocked by what I am about to say here, do not hold it against me that, while speaking of sorrows which need heroes to bear them, I can talk of children.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is a sign of a well-behaved child that it is disposed to ask permission without pondering too deeply whether it is in the right or not; and so it is a sign of a magnanimous man of profound soul that he is disposed to repent, that he does not go to law with God but repents and loves God in his repentance.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Without that his life is nothing, merely like foam on water.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yes, I assure you that if my own life, through no fault of my own, were so fraught with sorrows and sufferings that I could call myself the greatest tragic hero, revel in my pain, and appal the world by calling attention to it, my choice is made; I divest myself of the hero’s apparel and of tragedy’s pathos, I am not the afflicted one who can be proud of his suffering, I am the humble one who is aware of his sin.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I have only one expression for what I suffer – guilt; one expression for my pain – repentance; one hope before my eyes – forgiveness; and if I find this difficult, ah!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I have but one prayer, I will throw myself to the ground and implore the eternal power that governs the world for one grace, early and late, that I be allowed to repent.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For I know only one sorrow which can bring me to despair and plunge everything down into it – the sorrow that repentance was a delusion, a delusion not in respect of the forgiveness it seeks, but in the accountability it presupposes.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And do you think that this conduct shows that I fail to give sorrow its due, that I am running away from it?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: By no means!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I deposit it within my being and for that reason I never forget it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: By and large it is mistrust of the validity of spirit not to dare to believe that I can have something within me without looking at it at every instant.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In everyday life whatever one most wishes to set aside one deposits in a place one does not come to every day; so too in a spiritual sense.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I have sorrow within me, and I know that it will continue to be part of my being.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I know it far more surely than someone who from dread of losing it takes it out every day.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: My life has never been so agitated that I felt tempted by the chaotic wish to throw all existence into confusion, but in my daily life I have often discovered how profitable it is to give sorrow an ethical expression, not to erase the aesthetic factor in sorrow but to master it ethically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: As long as sorrow is quiet and humble, I do not fear it; if it becomes vehement and passionate, sophistical so that it deludes me into despondency, I arise, I brook no rebellion, I will have nothing in the world cheat me of what I have from God’s hand as a gift of grace.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I do not chase sorrow away, do not try to forget it, I repent.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Perhaps you see now why I take up this life-view here.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Personal being is here again viewed under the category of necessity, and there is only enough freedom left constantly to keep the individual half awake, as in a restless dream, and to lead him astray into the labyrinth of suffering and dispensation where he sees himself everywhere yet cannot come to himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is incredible how irresponsibly one sees problems like these dealt with.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Even systematic thinkers treat [freedom] as a natural curiosity they have nothing more to say about, but can only describe, without it ever occurring to them that, if there were such a natural curiosity, all the rest of their wisdom is nonsense and illusion.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That is why one feels helped quite otherwise by the Christian view than by all the wisdom of the philosophers.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It assigns everything to sin, something philosophy is too aesthetic to have the ethical courage to do.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And yet this courage is the only thing that can save life and man, unless one is to break off one’s scepticism at a whim and join forces with some like-minded persons on what to count as true.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The first form the choice takes is a complete isolation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For in choosing myself I sever myself from my relationship to the whole world until, in this separation, I end in an abstract identity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: When the individual has chosen himself in respect of his freedom he is by that very fact active.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yet his action has no relation to any surrounding world, for the individual has completely done away with the latter and is only for himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The life-view here presented is, however, an ethical view.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In Greece it was expressed in a single individual’s endeavour to develop himself into a paragon of virtue.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: As later with the anchorites in Christendom, one withdrew from life’s activities, not to steep oneself in metaphysical musings, but to act, not outwardly, but within oneself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This inner action was at once the individual’s task and satisfaction, for it was no part of his purpose to cultivate himself the better to be able to serve the State later on; no, in this cultivation the individual was sufficient unto himself and abandoned the life of the State, never to return to it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Really, then, one didn’t withdraw from life; on the contrary, one remained within its diversity because contact with it was pedagogically necessary for one’s own sake; but civic life as such had no significance for one – through some or other sorcerer’s spell one had rendered it harmless, indifferent, unimportant.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So the virtues the individual developed were not civic virtues (as the virtues in paganism really were, corresponding to the religious virtues in Christianity), they were the personal virtues: courage, perseverance, temperance, moderation, etc.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Naturally, in our own times one very seldom sees this life-view put into practice, since everyone is too much affected by the religious to stay with such an abstract specification of virtue.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is easy to see what the defect is with this life-view.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The error is that the individual has chosen himself altogether abstractly, and so the perfection he desired and attained was similarly abstract.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It was for that reason I stressed that choosing oneself and repenting oneself are identical, for repentance puts the individual into the most heartfelt connection, and the most intimate cohesion, with the surrounding world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Analogies to this Greek view have often been seen, even occasionally in the Christian world, except that in Christianity a seasoning of mystical and religious elements makes it richer and more beautiful.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Whatever heights of virtuosity a Greek who developed himself into a perfect compendium of all personal virtues might attain, his life is still no less mortal than the world whose temptation his virtue conquered; his blessedness is a lonely self-contentment, transient as everything else.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Now, the life of a mystic is far deeper.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He has chosen himself absolutely, for although a mystic is less often heard to express himself in this way, although he generally uses the seemingly opposite expression that he has chosen God, it comes to the same as was shown above.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For unless he has chosen himself absolutely he is not in any free relationship to God, and the characteristic of Christian piety lies in freedom.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In the language of the mystic this free relationship to God is often expressed by saying that He is the absolute Thou.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The mystic has chosen himself absolutely, according therefore to his freedom, and consequently is by that very fact active, but his action is inner action.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The mystic chooses himself in his complete isolation; for him the whole world is dead and done away with and the weary soul chooses God, or itself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This expression, ‘the weary soul’, must not be misunderstood, not misused to demean the mystic as if there were something dubious about the soul’s choosing God only when it had become weary of the world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: No doubt what the mystic is conveying through this expression is his repentance at not having chosen God earlier, and his weariness should not be regarded as the same thing as boredom with life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here already you will see how little the mystic’s life is given to the ethical, since the highest expression of his repentance is to repent that he had not chosen God earlier, before he became concrete in the world, while his soul was merely abstractly defined, that is, as a child.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The mystic, in having chosen, is by that very fact active.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But his action is inner action.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Inasmuch as he is active his life has a movement, a development, a history.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However, a development can be metaphysical or aesthetic to such a degree that it is doubtful whether in any proper sense one should call it a history, since one thinks of that as a development in the form of freedom.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A movement can be haphazard to such a degree that one can doubt whether it should be called a development.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Thus, if the movement consists in the same factor occurring again and again, undeniably we have movement, indeed one can perhaps discover a law of its motion; but we have no development.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The repetition in time is without meaning, and continuity is lacking.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This is very largely true of the life of the mystic.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A mystic’s meanings about the moments of dullness make appalling reading.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But when the dull moment has gone there comes the moment of light, and so his life is constantly changing, it has movement indeed, but no development.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: His life lacks continuity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What really provides that in the life of the mystic is a feeling, namely longing, whether this longing is directed at what has gone or at what is to come.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But the fact that what makes up the interval is a feeling shows precisely that cohesion is lacking.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A mystic’s development is metaphysically and aesthetically determined to such a degree that one can hardly call it history, except in the sense in which one speaks of the history of a plant.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For the mystic, the whole world is dead, he has fallen in love with God.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The development of his life is then the unfolding of this love.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Just as there are instances of lovers bearing some resemblance to one another, even outwardly, in their expression, their physiognomy, so is the mystic absorbed in the contemplation of the Deity, and the latter’s image is more and more reflected in his loving soul; thus the mystic renews and revives the lost divine image in man.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The more he contemplates, the more clearly this image is reflected in him, the more he comes himself to resemble this image.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: His inner action consists not, then, in the acquisition of the personal virtues but in the development of the religious or contemplative virtues.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yet even this is too ethical an expression for his life, and his real life is therefore prayer.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That prayer is also part of an ethical life I will not deny, but the more ethically a man lives, the more the prayer has the character of an intention, so that there is an element of intention even in the prayer of thanksgiving.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: With the mystic’s prayer it is otherwise.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For him prayer means all the more the more erotic it is, the more it is inflamed by a burning love.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The prayer is the expression of his love, the only language in which he can address the Deity with whom he has fallen in love.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: As in earthly life the lovers long for the moment when they can breathe their love to one another, let their souls fuse in a soft whisper, so the mystic longs for the moment when in his prayer he can, as it were, steal into the presence of God.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: As the lovers experience in that whisper their greatest bliss when really they have nothing at all to talk about, so the mystic in his prayer is all the more blessed, his love all the more happy, the less content there is in it, the more nearly in his sigh he vanishes from before his own very eyes.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Perhaps it would not be too much of a diversion here to bring out more clearly what is untrue in such a life, especially since a person of any profundity is always liable to be impressed by it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Thus you yourself are by no means lacking in what it takes to be a mystic, at least for a while.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This is, in general, the area where the greatest contrasts meet, the purest and most innocent souls and the guiltiest, the most gifted and the most simple-minded.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: First I will state, quite simple-mindedly, what really offends me in such a life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This is my personal judgement.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Later I shall try to show the accuracy of my indications of its dubious sides, as well as the reasons for these and the fearful false paths that lie so close.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In my opinion one cannot exonerate the mystic from a certain importunity in his relationship to God.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That a man should love God with all his soul and with all his mind, and not merely should do so but that his actually doing so is blessedness itself, who could deny?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However, from this it by no means follows that the mystic should disdain the existence, the reality, in which God has placed him; for in that case he is really disdaining God’s love, or demanding another expression of it than the one God wants to give.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here Samuel’s serious saying applies: ‘To obey is better than sacrifice, and to hearken than the fat of rams.’27 But this importunity can occasionally take on an even more questionable form, as when a mystic justifies his relationship to God on the grounds of being the very person he is, and thinks that it is due to some accidental trait that he is the object of God’s partiality.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For here he debases the Deity and himself: himself because it is always a debasement to be essentially distinguished from others by something accidental; God because he makes the Deity a false god and himself into a favourite at his court.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What next I find displeasing in a mystic’s life is the softness and weakness from which one cannot exonerate him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That a man wishes to be assured in his inmost heart that he loves God truly and sincerely, that he many a time feels the need to be properly convinced of this, that he can pray God to let his Spirit bear witness that he does so,28 who would deny the beauty and truth in that?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But from this it by no means follows that at every moment he will repeat this attempt, that at every moment he will put his love to the test.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He wants to have greatness of soul enough to believe in God’s love, but then he should also have the confidence to believe in his own love, and to continue happily in the situation assigned to him, precisely because he knows that this continuation is the surest expression of his love, of his humility.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Finally, a mystic’s life displeases me because I consider it a deceit against the world in which he lives, a deceit against those with whom he is associated or with whom he could enter into relationships had it not pleased him to become a mystic.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Generally the mystic chooses the solitary life, but that does not clarify the situation, for the question is whether he has a right to choose it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Inasmuch as it is something he has chosen, he does not deceive others, for this is to say in effect, ‘I will have no relationship with you’, but the question is whether he has a right to say that, a right to do this.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is especially as a husband, as a father, that I am an enemy of mysticism.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: My household has also its adyton,29 but if I were a mystic I would also have to have yet another all for myself, and then I would be a bad husband.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Now since in my view, as I shall explain later, it is every man’s duty to marry, and since it cannot possibly be my view that one should marry in order to become a bad husband, you will easily see that I must have an aversion to all mysticism.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In the end someone who devotes himself one-sidedly to a life of mysticism becomes so much a stranger to everyone that he becomes indifferent to every relationship, even the tenderest and most heartfelt.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is not in this sense that one is to love God more than father and mother;30 God is not that self-loving, nor is he a poet who wishes to torment men with the most fearful collisions, and you could hardly conceive anything more fearful than that there indeed existed a collision between love of God and love of those human beings our love of whom He has lodged in our hearts.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You have surely not forgotten young Ludvig Blackfeldt, with whom we both had so much contact a few years ago, particularly myself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Certainly he had great mental gifts, but his misfortune was to become one-sidedly absorbed not so much in Christian as in Indian mysticism.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Had he lived in the Middle Ages, he would undoubtedly have found refuge in a monastery.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Our own age has no such expedients.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If a person loses his way now he must needs go under unless he is completely cured; we have no such relative salvation to offer him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You know he ended by taking his own life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Poor Ludvig was not indeed religiously affected, but he was affected mystically nevertheless; for what is peculiar to the mystical is not the religious but the isolation in which the individual, not heeding any relation with the given reality, would put himself into immediate rapport with the eternal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The fact that the word ‘mysticism’ naturally and immediately calls something religious to mind has to do with the fact that religion has a tendency to isolate the individual, as the most simple observation can convince you.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Maybe you attend church rather infrequently, but you are likely to be all the more observant.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Have you noticed that although in a sense one gets the impression of a congregation, the individual still feels isolated?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: People become strangers to each other, and it is as though one were united again only by way of a long detour.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And to what is this due if not to the individual’s feeling his God-relationship so strongly, in all its inwardness, that his earthly relationships lose their importance beside it?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For a healthy man this instant will not last long, and a momentary distancing of this kind is so far from being a deceit that, rather, it increases the inwardness of the earthly relationships.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But what can be healthy as a constituent becomes a most critical sickness when developed one-sidedly.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Not having a theological background, I do not consider myself capable of elaborating on the subject of religious mysticism any further.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I have considered it only from my ethical standpoint, and have therefore, correctly I believe, given the word ‘mysticism’ a much broader meaning than usual.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That there is very much that is beautiful in religious mysticism, that the many deep and serious natures who have devoted themselves to it have experienced much in their lives, and were thus qualified to provide counsel and directions and hints of service to others who would venture upon this dangerous path, of that I have no doubt; yet this path is notwithstanding not merely a dangerous path but a false one.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: There is always an inconsistency implicit in it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Since the mystic has no respect at all for reality, it is not evident why he does not treat with the same distrust that moment in reality when he became affected by higher things.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So the mystic’s fault is not that he chooses himself, for in my opinion he does well to do that, his mistake is that he does not choose himself properly; he chooses in respect of his freedom and yet he does not choose ethically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One can only choose oneself in respect of one’s freedom when one chooses oneself ethically; but one can only choose oneself ethically by repenting oneself, and it is only by repenting oneself that one becomes concrete, and it is only as a concrete individual that one is a free individual.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The mystic’s mistake does not lie in something later but in the very first movement.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If one takes that to be correct, then every withdrawal from life, every ascetic self-torment is simply a further and proper consequence.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The mystic’s mistake is that in the choice he does not become concrete for himself, and not for God either; he chooses himself abstractly and therefore lacks transparency.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For if you believe that the abstract is the transparent, you are mistaken; the abstract is the opaque, the indistinct.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Therefore his love for God has its highest expression in a feeling, a mood; in the evening twilight, in the season of mists, he melts with vague movements into one with his God.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But when one chooses oneself abstractly, one does not choose oneself ethically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Only when one has taken possession of oneself in the choice, has attired oneself in one’s self, has penetrated oneself so totally that every movement is attended by the consciousness of a responsibility for oneself, only then has one chosen oneself ethically, only then has one repented oneself, only then is one concrete, only then is one, in one’s total isolation, in absolute continuity with the reality one belongs to.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I cannot return often enough to this proviso that choosing oneself is identical with repenting oneself, however simple in itself it may be.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For upon this everything turns.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The mystic too repents, but he repents himself out of himself, not into himself, he repents metaphysically, not ethically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: To repent aesthetically is detestable because it is effeminate; to repent metaphysically is a misplaced superfluity, for the individual has not created the world after all, and so need not take it so much to heart if the world should really turn out to be vanity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The mystic chooses himself abstractly and therefore has to repent himself abstractly too.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This can best be seen from the mystic’s judgement upon existence, the finite reality in which he lives.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For the mystic teaches that it is vanity, illusion, sin; but every such judgement is a metaphysical judgement and does not define my relation to existence ethically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Even when he says that finitude is sin, what he says is just about the same as when he calls it vanity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If, on the other hand, he were to keep hold of the ethical sense of the word ‘sin’, he would define his relation to it not ethically but metaphysically, for the ethical expression would not be to run away from it but to enter into it, to abolish it or to bear it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Ethical repentance has but two movements; either it abolishes its object or it bears it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: These two movements also indicate a concrete relation between the repenting individual and the object of his repentance, whereas fleeing expresses an abstract relation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The mystic chooses himself abstractly, and one can therefore say that he constantly chooses himself out of the world; but the consequence is that he cannot choose himself back again into the world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The true concrete choice is that in which in the very moment I choose myself out of the world I choose myself back into it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For when I choose myself repentantly I gather myself together in all my finite concretion, and in thus having chosen myself out of the finite I am in the most absolute continuity with it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The greatest significance [the mystic] can assign to the temporal is to see it as a period of probation in which one must be repeatedly tested without any real result or getting any further than at the beginning.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This, however, is to misjudge the temporal, for although it does always retain something of an ecclesia pressa,31 it is at the same time the possibility of the finite spirit’s glorification.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is precisely the beauty of the finite that within it infinite spirit and finite spirit are separated, and it is precisely the greatness of the finite spirit that the temporal is assigned to it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So the temporal does not exist, if I may be so bold, for God’s sake so that in it He can, mystically speaking, test and try the one who loves; it is there for man’s sake and is the greatest of all gifts of grace.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For the eternal dignity of man lies in the fact that he can acquire a history, and the divine element in him lies in the fact that he himself can impart to this history a continuity if he will; for it acquires that not by being the sum of all that has happened to or befallen me, but by being my own work, so that even what has befallen me is transformed in me and translated from necessity to freedom.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The enviable thing with a human life is that one can come to the aid of the Deity, can understand Him, and again the only way of understanding Him worthy of a man is freely to appropriate all that has fallen to one, both the joyful and the sorrowful.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Or does it not seem so to you?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That is how it strikes me; yes, I think one would only have to say it aloud to a man to make him envious of himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The two standpoints indicated here [the Greek and the mystical] might be regarded as attempts to realize an ethical view of life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The reason why they do not succeed is that the individual has chosen himself in his isolation or has chosen himself abstractly.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This can also be put by saying that the individual has not chosen himself ethically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He is therefore not connected with reality, and in that case no ethical life-view can be put into practice.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: On the other hand, a person who chooses himself ethically chooses himself concretely as this definite individual, and he achieves this concretion by the choice being identical with the repentance which sanctions the choice.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The individual is then aware of himself as this definite individual, with these aptitudes, these tendencies, these instincts, these passions, influenced by these definite surroundings, as this definite product of a definite outside world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But in becoming self-aware in this way, he assumes responsibility for it all.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He does not pause to consider whether to include some particular trait or not, for he knows there is something far higher that he stands to lose if he does not.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: At the instant of choice, then, he is in the most complete isolation for he withdraws from the surroundings, and yet is at the same instant in absolute continuity for he chooses himself as product; and this choice is freedom’s choice, so that in choosing himself as product he can just as well be said to produce himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: At the instant of choice, then, he is at the conclusion, for his personhood forms a closure; and yet in the same instant he is precisely at the beginning for he chooses himself in respect of his freedom.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: As product he is pressed into the forms of reality, in the choice he makes himself elastic, he transforms the whole of his outwardness to inwardness.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He has his place in the world, with freedom he himself chooses his place, that is, he chooses this place.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He is a definite individual, in the choice he makes himself into a definite individual, that is to say, into the same, for he chooses himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The individual thus chooses himself as a diversely determined concretion, and chooses himself therefore in respect of his concretion.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This concretion is the reality of the individual, but since it is in respect of his freedom that he chooses it, one can also say that it is his possibility, or, to avoid such an aesthetic expression, that it is his task.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For the person who lives aesthetically sees only possibilities everywhere; for him it is these that form the content of the future, whereas the person who lives ethically sees tasks everywhere.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is then this real concretion of his that the individual sees as his task, his goal, his aim.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But the fact that it is his own possibility that the individual sees as his task expresses precisely his sovereignty over himself, which he never surrenders even though he does not enjoy the highly unencumbered sovereignty that a king without a country always has.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This gives the ethical individual a sense of security which someone living merely aesthetically altogether lacks.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The person who lives aesthetically expects everything from outside, hence the sickly anxiety with which many speak of the dreadful circumstance of not having found one’s place in the world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Who would deny the satisfaction in being fortunate in this respect?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But such an anxiety is always an indication that the individual expects everything from the place and nothing from himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The person who lives ethically will try to choose his place rightly, but if he notices that he has chosen wrongly, or that obstacles arise over which he has no control, he does not lose courage for he never surrenders his sovereignty over himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He at once sees his task and is therefore instantly active.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality
