chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But you may be sure that for this faith in the victory of the beautiful I will engage in mortal combat, and nothing in the world can wrest it from me.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Even if one wished to wrest it from me through prayer, to snatch it from me by force, not for anything in the world would I let myself be deprived of it, for if I lost that faith I would lose the whole world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Through this faith I see the beauty of life, and the beauty I see does not have the sadness and melancholy that are inseparable from all beauty in nature and art, inseparable even from the eternal youth of the Greek gods.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The beauty I see is joyful and triumphant, and stronger than all the world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And this beauty I see everywhere, even where your eye sees nothing.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let us now come a little closer to some real-life situations, especially of the kind where the aesthetic and the ethical come into contact with each other, so as to consider how far the ethical view deprives us of any beauty or see if it does not rather bestow on everything a higher beauty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I am thinking of some definite individual, in a sense like anyone else, but in another sense concrete in himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let us be quite prosaic.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This person has to live, clothe himself, in short has to be able to exist.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Suppose he turned to an aesthete to find out how to manage his life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Then information will at least not be something he goes short of.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The latter might say to him, ‘When one is single one needs three thousand dollars a year to live comfortably, if one has four thousand so much the better; if one wants to get married one needs at least six thousand.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Money, after all, is and remains the motivation for doing things, the true that-without-which  It is the absolute condition of life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: As soon as one has no money one is and remains excluded from the numbers of the patricians, one is and remains a plebeian.’  If he were to say to the aesthete, ‘That’s all very well, but I have neither three thousand nor six thousand a year, I have nothing, either in capital or in interest, I have absolutely nothing at all, hardly a hat’, the latter would shrug his shoulders and say, ‘Well, that’s another matter, then there’s nothing for it but to put up with the workhouse.’ Were he extremely good-natured the aesthete might perhaps beckon again to the poor devil and say to him, ‘I wouldn’t have you driven to despair without my hazarding the most extreme measures; there are a few makeshifts one shouldn’t leave untried before bidding farewell to joy for ever and signing the pledge and putting on the straitjacket.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Marry a rich girl, play the lottery, travel to the colonies, spend some years scraping together some money, curry favour with an old bachelor so that he makes you his heir.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For the moment our ways separate, get the money and you will always find in me a friend who knows how to forget there was a time when you had none.’ But there is something dreadfully heartless after all in such a view of life – murdering in cold blood all joy in life for everyone who has no money.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And that is what a moneyed person of this kind does, for at least it is his opinion that there is no joy in life without money.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: [But] let us now hear how an ethicist would reply to him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: His answer would be as follows: ‘It is every man’s duty to work in order to live.’ Had he nothing more to say, you would presumably reply, ‘Here we have the same old talk again of duty and duty, everywhere duty; anything more tedious than this astringent which dispirits and amputates everything is unimaginable.’ Please recall that our hero had no money  and unless he wanted simply to think of what he would have done if he did have some, he would have had to be prepared for some other expedient.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Note, too, that the ethicist addressed him with all politeness, he did not treat him as an exception, he did not say: ‘Good Lord!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: How unfortunate, you must try to put up with it.’ On the contrary, he made the aesthete an exception, for he said, ‘It is every man’s duty to work in order to live.’ In so far, then, as a man need not do so, he is an exception, but  there is nothing great, only inferior, in being an exception.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Therefore if someone wants to look at the matter ethically he will see that having money is a humiliation, for every special favour is a humiliation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One could wish that in this respect people had rather more courage, and the reason why one often hears so much of this contemptible clamour about money being the main thing is partly that those who have to work lack the ethical energy to acknowledge the significance of working and have no ethical conviction of its significance.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Marriage is not harmed by seducers but by cowardly husbands.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So too here.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That contemptible talk does no harm, but the good cause is harmed by those who, being compelled to work in order to live, at one moment want their life to be recognized as deserving compared with that of idlers, the next complain and sigh and say, ‘The finest thing, after all, is to be independent.’  The question whether one might not imagine a world in which it was not necessary to work in order to live is really an idle one, since it concerns not given reality but a fiction.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Asking it, however, is always an attempt to belittle the ethical view.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For if it were a perfection on the part of existence that work was unnecessary, the most perfect life would be that of someone who did not have to work.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It could then only be by attaching to the word ‘duty’ the sense of a lamentable necessity that one could say it was a duty to work.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Duty would then express not the universally human but what is general, and here duty would not express perfection.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Therefore I would reply quite properly that it would have to be considered an imperfection on the part of existence that man had no need to work.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The lower the level of human life, the less the necessity of work is apparent; the higher, the more obvious it becomes.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The duty of working in order to live expresses the universally human, and expresses the universal in another way too because it expresses freedom.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is precisely through work that man makes himself free, through work he becomes master of nature, through work he shows he is higher than nature.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: [What] struggle could be more formative than that of making ends meet!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I shall not insist so adamantly on my rights as to challenge you to make clear just where in your aesthetics you deal with this matter; I merely leave it to you to consider whether in this struggle life loses its beauty if one does not will it so, or whether it does not gain a higher beauty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: To deny that such a struggle exists is madness; to forget it because it passes you by is thoughtlessness, and inasmuch as one pretends to a view of life, callousness or cowardice.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So the ethical view that it is every man’s duty to work in order to live has two advantages over the aesthetic view.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In the first place, it accords with reality and explains something universal in the latter, while the aesthetic proposes something accidental and explains nothing.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Second, it construes man in the light of his perfection, sees him in view of his true beauty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This must be regarded as being all that is necessary and more than sufficient on this subject.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: [But] perhaps [our hero] cannot yet make up his mind to have recourse to the ethicist.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He ventures one more attempt.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He meets a man who says, ‘One must work in order to live, that’s just the way life is.’ Here it looks as if he had found what he was looking for, since that is just what he thinks too.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So this is talk he will listen to: ‘One has to work in order to live, that’s just the way life is, it is the threadbare side of existence.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One sleeps seven hours a day, that’s time wasted but it can’t be helped.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Five hours’ work a day gets you your livelihood and once you have that you start living.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So one’s work had better be as dull and meaningless as possible, as long as one gets a living from it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If one has some special talent one must never commit the sin against it of making it one’s means of livelihood.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: No, one coddles one’s talent, it’s something one has for one’s own sake, and one has greater joy of it than a mother has of her child.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One cultivates it, develops it, in the twelve hours of the day, sleeps for seven, is a non-human for five, and so life becomes pretty bearable after all – yes, even quite nice, since the five hours’ work don’t matter so much, seeing that when one’s thoughts are never on the work one is gathering strength for the pursuit in which one’s pleasure lies.’ Our hero is again no nearer his goal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In the first place he has no talent with which to fill up the twelve hours at home; second, he already has a more attractive view of what it is to work which he will not give up.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So probably he will resolve once more to seek help from the ethicist.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The ethicist speaks briefly: ‘It is every man’s duty to work in order to live.’ More he cannot say, for the ethical as such is always abstract and there is no such thing as an abstract vocation for all men; on the contrary, he assumes every person has a special vocation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The life-views of the aesthete are always based on difference: some men have talent, others not, yet what distinguishes them is a more-or-less, a quantitative specification.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In a way it is arbitrary on the aesthete’s part to stop at any particular point, and yet it is precisely in this arbitrariness one finds the nerve of [this] life-view.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It therefore divides existence against itself in a way [the aesthetes] find themselves unable to resolve, and in return they seek irresponsibly and callously to arm themselves against it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The ethicist, on the other hand, reconciles man with life, for he says, ‘Everyone has a vocation.’ He does not do away with differences but says, ‘Behind all differences there remains the universal, and it is a vocation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The most eminent talent is a vocation, and the individual who possesses it cannot lose sight of reality, he doesn’t stand outside the universally human for his talent is a vocation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The least significant individual has a vocation, he won’t be cast out, or sent to live next to the beasts, he doesn’t stand outside the universally human, he has a vocation.’ So the ethical proposition that everyone has a vocation implies a rational order of things in which every person, if he wants, fills his place in such a way that he expresses the universally human and the individual simultaneously.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Does existence become the less beautiful for this view?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One has no aristocracy to rejoice in, whose significance is based on accident and based on that accidentally; no, one has a kingdom of gods.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Our hero, then, has got what he was looking for: a work by which to live.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: At the same time he has got a more significant expression of its relation to his personality: his work is his vocation, consequently accomplishing it is bound up with a satisfaction of his whole personal being.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: At the same time he has got a more significant expression of the relation of his work to others, for since his work is his vocation he is put essentially on the same footing with all other men, so that in carrying on his work he is doing essentially the same as all others.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So the ethical view that everyone has a vocation has two advantages over the aesthetic theory of talent.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In the first place what it makes transparent is not something accidental in existence but the universal; second, it displays the universal in its true beauty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Talent is beautiful only when it becomes transparent in a vocation, and existence is beautiful only when everyone has a vocation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That being so, I will beg you not to sneeze at a simple empirical observation which so far as our main topic is concerned you will have the goodness to regard as gratuitous.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If a person has a vocation he generally has a standard outside him which, without making him a slave, nevertheless prescribes to some extent what he is to do, apportions his time for him, gives him frequently the opportunity to begin.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If for once he should not succeed in his job, he hopes to do it better next time, and this next time is not too far distant.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: On the other hand, someone who does not have a vocation, if he sets himself a task at all, will usually have to work without a break.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He gets no respite that is not also an interruption brought about in himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If he fails, everything fails, and because the occasion to do so is not there he has extreme difficulty getting going again.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So he is easily tempted to become a pedant, unless he becomes a loafer.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is such common practice to denounce people who perform definite functions as pedants.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: As a rule such a person simply cannot become a pedant.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: On the other hand, there is a temptation for someone without any definite function to become one in order to put up at least some resistance to that all too great freedom in which he can so easily lose his way.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One may therefore be generally inclined to forgive him his pedantry, for it is a sign of something good.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: On the other hand, it has still to be considered a punishment, because he has wanted to emancipate himself from the common practice.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: [The ethicist] says, ‘What every man does and can accomplish is to do his job in life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For if it were the case that there were some people who accomplished something and others who didn’t, and the reason for this lay in their contingent abilities, then scepticism would again have the upper hand.’ One can therefore say, ‘Essentially everyone accomplishes as much as anyone else.’ I am by no means preaching indolence, but on the other hand one must be careful how one uses the word ‘accomplish’; it has always been a butt of your ridicule.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Which is why, as you once put it, you have ‘studied integral, differential and infinitesimal calculus in order to reckon what part of the whole was accomplished by a junior Admiralty clerk, reckoned by the whole office a competent worker’.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Use your ridicule only upon those who would affect importance in life; never misuse it to confuse people.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The word ‘accomplish’ indicates a relation between my action and something else outside me.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Now it is easy to see that I have no authority over this relation and, to that extent, one can say of the most talented person that he accomplishes nothing, just as one can of the least able.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: There is no implicit distrust of life in this, on the contrary there is an implicit recognition of my own insignificance and a respect for the significance of every other person.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He who has the greatest talent can complete his job, and so also can the least able.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Neither can do more.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Whether they are to accomplish anything is not in their power, whereas it is indeed in their power to prevent themselves from doing so.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I therefore disclaim all that self-importance that calls so much attention to itself in life; I do my job and do not waste my time calculating whether I accomplish anything.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So what I accomplish as a result of my work is my good fortune, in which I might well dare to rejoice but which I do not impute altogether to myself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A growing beech forms its crown of leaves and men enjoy sitting in its shade.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Were it to become impatient, if it were to say, ‘Here where I stand there hardly ever comes a living being, so what good is it that I grow, that I spread out my branches, what do I accomplish by that?’, it might merely delay its own growth and perhaps one day there might come a wayfarer who said, ‘If, instead of being stunted, this tree had been a leafy beech I could have been resting now in its shade.’ Think if the tree had been able to hear!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So our hero works for his living; this work is also his pleasure; he follows his vocation, he does his job; in one word, and it is a word that seizes you with dread – he has a living  What then?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You smile, you think I have something up my sleeve.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You shudder already at the thought of my unimaginative common sense, for ‘now it’s going to end up for sure in nothing less than getting him married, yes, please, go ahead, publish the banns for him, I shall have no objection to raise against his and your divine intention.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What an incredible rational consistency there is in life ; with a living comes a wife.’  [But] you can still hold out hope for a while, just as long as I must remain anxious.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Since our hero is no different from anyone else he has some inclination towards the uncommon; he is also a little ungrateful.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So before taking refuge with the ethicist he wants to try his luck once more with the aesthetes.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He also knows how to put a good face on his ingratitude; he says, ‘The ethicist really did help me out of my confusion, I am completely satisfied with the way he got me to look at the reality of my life, its seriousness uplifts me.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But as far as love is concerned, there I could well wish to enjoy my freedom, simply follow the impulse of my heart; love does not love this seriousness, it demands the levity and charm of the aesthetic.’  Although you never replied to my previous letter, verbally or in writing, you no doubt remember its content, and how I tried there to show that marriage was, by virtue of the ethical, precisely the aesthetic expression of love.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Presumably, then, you will give me credit for what was expounded there, in the assurance that to the extent I have succeeded in making it intelligible to you, I will be able, if need be, to explain it to our hero.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He has resorted to the aesthetes and he has departed from them none the wiser what he should do but rather what he should not.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For a little while he has been witness to a seducer’s cunning, has listened to his fawning talk, but has learnt to despise his art, has learnt to see through him, to see that he is a liar, a liar when he feigns love, when he puts fresh paint on feelings which perhaps once had some truth in them when he belonged in them to another, that he deceives doubly, her to whom he pretends to cherish them and her to whom they rightly belong, a liar when he pretends to himself that there is something beautiful in his desire.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He has learnt to despise the clever ridicule that would turn love into a childish prank at which one should only smile.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For a while he has let himself be lulled by the distrust of life that would teach him that everything is transitory, that time changes everything, that one dare not build on anything and therefore never form a plan for one’s whole life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A latent indolence and cowardice found this talk quite acceptable, it was a comfortable costume to assume and in other people’s eyes not unbecoming.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Nevertheless, he has looked closely at this talk, he has seen the hypocrite, seen the pleasure-lover who came in humble dress, the beast of prey that came in sheep’s clothing, and he has learnt to despise this talk.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He has perceived that it was an insult and therefore ungracious to want to love a person on the basis of what in his own nature was obscure and not of what was conscious, to want to love in such a way that he could imagine it possible that this love should cease and then that he could bring himself to say, ‘So there’s nothing I can do, a man has no power over his feelings.’ He has perceived that it was an insult and therefore ungracious to want to love with one part of the soul but not with all of it, to treat one’s own love as one element and yet take the whole of another’s love, to want to be something of a riddle and a secret.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He has perceived that it would be unseemly if he had a hundred arms so that he could simultaneously embrace many; he has but one embrace and wants to embrace only one.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He has perceived that it was an insult to want to attach himself to another person in the way one attaches oneself to finite and accidental things, conditionally, so that if difficulties later arose one could make a change.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He does not believe it possible that a man who loves can change, except for the better, and if it did happen he believes in the power of the relationship to make all well again.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He recognizes that what love demands is, like the temple tribute, a holy tax which is paid in its own currency, and that one does not accept all the world’s riches as release from the slightest demand if the stamp is false.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Our hero, you see, is on the right path, he has lost his faith in the aesthetes’ callous common sense and in their superstitious belief in obscure emotions that are supposed to be too delicate to be expressed as duty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He has gratefully accepted the ethicist’s statement that it is every man’s duty to marry; he has understood this correctly, not as saying that it is a sin not to marry, unless it is one’s own fault, for then he sins against the universally human with which he is also presented as a task, but as saying he who marries realizes the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Further the ethicist cannot bring him, for as we have said, the ethical is always abstract and it can only tell him what the universal is.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So, in this case, it can by no means tell him whom he should marry, for that would require close familiarity with all his aesthetic characteristics, but the ethicist does not have that, and if he did he would still be careful not to make nonsense of his own theories by making the choice for him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So when he has made his own choice, the ethical will sanction it and elevate his love, and to some extent it will also help him in his choice by saving him from a superstitious belief in the accidental.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However, there is still a sharp corner we must turn before we are safely home.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For our hero has heard a man, whose judgement and opinion he respects, express the view that since in a marriage one ties oneself to a person for the whole of one’s life, one must be careful in one’s choice, it must be an uncommon girl whose uncommon qualities are just those needed to give one security for the whole of one’s future.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Do you not feel inclined to have some hopes for our hero for just a little longer?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I at least feel anxious for him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let us deal thoroughly with this question.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: [Suppose] in the solitary stillness of the forest there dwells a nymph, a being, a girl.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Very well then, this nymph, girl, this being, abandons her solitude and turns up here in Copenhagen  and our hero becomes the lucky man upon whom she bestows her love.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: [He] is in a critical position.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: About the girl there is but one opinion: this is an uncommon girl.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I myself, a married man, say with Donna Clara, ‘Here rumour has not exaggerated, she is a prodigy of a child, the beautiful Preciosa.’45 It is so tempting to lose sight of the common and float in fairy-tale waftings.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yet he has perceived what is beautiful in marriage.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What, then, does marriage do?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Take something from him?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Take from her some of her beauty?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Abolish one single difference?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Not at all.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What it does, however, is make all these look accidental so long as marriage is something outside him; it is only when he gives the difference the expression of the universal, it is only then that he is secure in his possession of it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The ethical teaches him that the relationship is the absolute, for the relationship is the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It deprives him of the vain joy of being uncommon in order to give him the true joy of being ordinary.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It brings him into harmony with all existence, teaches him to rejoice in it, for as an exception, as the uncommon, he is in conflict with it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Since in this case it was what counted as uncommon that gave him his good fortune, he must feel that his existence vexes what is common, provided there was truth in his good fortune; though surely it must truly be a misfortune to be fortunate in a way that, viewed essentially, one’s own good fortune differs from that of all others.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For what he does then is win the accidental beauty and lose the true beauty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This he will realize and he will return to the ethicist’s principle that it is every man’s duty to marry, and he will see that it has not just truth on its side but beauty too.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Suppose he gets this prodigy of a child.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He need fear no misfortune from gazing too long at the difference.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Her beauty, her charm, the wealth of her intelligence and the warmth of her feeling will give him genuine joy in his heart; he will count himself lucky, but essentially he will say, ‘I am no different from any other married man, for the relationship is the absolute.’ Suppose he gets a less gifted girl.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will be happy in his good fortune, for he will say, ‘Even if she is far inferior to others, essentially she makes me just as happy, for the relationship is the absolute.’ He will not fail to appreciate the importance of the difference, for as he realized there was no abstract vocation but that each person had his own, so he will realize that there is no abstract marriage.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Ethics tells him simply that he must marry; it does not tell him with whom.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Ethics makes the universal transparent to him in the difference, and he makes the difference transparent in the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So the ethical view of marriage has several advantages over any aesthetic understanding of love.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It highlights the universal, not the accidental.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It does not show how two altogether particular people in all their uncommonness could become happy, but how every married couple can become happy.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It sees the relationship as the absolute and so does not grasp the differences as guarantees but interprets them as tasks.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It sees the relationship as the absolute and therefore looks on love with a view to its true beauty, that is, with a view to its freedom; it understands historical beauty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Our hero lives, then, by his work; his work is at the same time his vocation and therefore he works with pleasure.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Its being his vocation puts him in association with other people, and in carrying out his job he accomplishes what he could wish to accomplish in the world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He is married, content in his home, and time passes excellently for him – he cannot comprehend how time could be a burden for anyone, or be an enemy of his happiness; on the contrary, it seems to him that time is a true blessing.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In this respect he admits that he owes a tremendous amount to his wife.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is true – I’m afraid I forgot to mention it – there was a misunderstanding with the nymph from the forest, he did not become the lucky one, he had to make do with a girl just like any other, just as he was a person just like any other.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However, for all that, he is very happy, yes, he once confided to me that he thought it rather a good thing he didn’t get that prodigy, the task would have been too much for him; where everything is so perfect before one starts it is all too easy to cause harm.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But now, however, he is full of courage and confidence and hope, his enthusiasm is complete, he says fervently, ‘After all, the relationship is the absolute.’ He is convinced more firmly than of anything else that the relationship will have the power to develop this ordinary girl into everything that is great and beautiful; his wife is, in all humility, of the same opinion.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: My hero – or would you deny him the right to the title?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: do you not think a courage that dares to believe that it can transform an ordinary girl into a prodigy is truly a hero’s courage?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: – my hero thanks his wife especially for the fact that time has acquired such a beautiful meaning for him, and he attributes this in turn to some extent to the marriage, and in that he and I, we two married men, entirely agree.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If he had got that nymph from the forest and had not married, he fears their love would have flared up in single beautiful moments which then left vapid intervals between them.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Then maybe they would only have wanted to see each other on properly meaningful occasions: had that failed several times he fears the whole relationship might gradually have dissolved into nothing.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The humble marriage, on the other hand, which made it a duty for them to see each other daily, for richer or poorer, had spread an equitableness and evenness over the whole relationship which makes him so very pleased with his marriage.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In its lowly incognito the prosaic marriage had concealed a poet who not only transfigured life now and then but was always at hand and thrilled even the poorer hours with his tones.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It happens sometimes that I sit down and inwardly collapse.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I have taken care of my work, I have no desire for diversion, and something melancholic in my temperament gains the upper hand.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I become much older than my actual years, I become a stranger to my domestic life almost; I see quite well how attractive it is, but I look at it with different eyes than usual; to me it is as if I were an old man, my wife a young sister who was happily married and in whose house I was now sitting.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In such hours time itself naturally begins to drag.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Now, were my wife a man perhaps the same would happen to her, and maybe both of us would come to a standstill.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But she is a woman and on good terms with time.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Is it a perfection on the part of woman, this secret rapport with time?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Is it an imperfection?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Is it because she is a more earthly being than man?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Or more because she has eternity within her?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You answer, for you have a philosophical mind.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: When I sit thus abandoned and lost, I look at my wife walk about in the room with light and youthful tread, always occupied, always with something to attend to, involuntarily my eyes follow her every movement and I join in everything she does, and it ends with my finding myself once more in time, with time acquiring meaning for me, the moment again moving swiftly.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yes, my good wise man, it is incredible what a natural virtuoso a woman is, she clarifies in the most interesting and beautiful way [this] problem [of time] that has cost many a philosopher his reason.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A problem for which in many philosophers, for all their prolixity, one searches for enlightenment in vain, she clarifies without further ado at any time of the day.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She clarifies it as she clarifies many others, in a way that arouses the deepest admiration.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Though not a husband of any long standing, I believe I could write a whole book on this topic.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However, I won’t do that, but will recount a story to you which says a great deal to me.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Somewhere in Holland there lived a scholar.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He was an orientalist and married.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One afternoon he fails to appear at mealtime in spite of being called.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: His wife waits expectantly with the food, she knows he is at home, and the longer this continues the less she can explain his absence.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Finally she decides to go along to him herself and urge him to come.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: There he is, sitting alone in his study, nobody with him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He is absorbed in his oriental studies.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I can picture it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She has bent down over him, put her arm round him, looked down at his book, then looking up at him, said, ‘Dear friend, why don’t you come along and eat?’ The scholar perhaps hardly had time to heed her words, but on seeing his wife he presumably replied, ‘Well, my girl, there can be no question of dinner, here is a diacritic I have never come across before – I have often seen the passage quoted but never in this way, and yet my edition is an excellent Dutch edition.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Look at this dot here, it’s enough to drive one mad.’ I can imagine his wife looked at him half smiling, half deprecating, at such a little dot disturbing the domestic order, and the tale recounts that she replied, ‘Is that anything to make such a fuss of?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It isn’t worth wasting one’s breath on.’ No sooner said than done.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She blows, and behold, the diacritic vanishes, for this remarkable dot was a grain of snuff.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The scholar hastens happily to the dinner-table, happy that the vowel point had disappeared, even happier in his wife.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Need I draw out the moral of this story?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Had that scholar not been married he might have gone crazy, and maybe taken several orientalists with him for I have no doubt that he would have raised an outcry in the literature.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That, you see, is why I say one should live on good terms with the opposite sex, for, between ourselves, a young girl clarifies everything and gives not a fig for the whole Academic Senate, and if one is on good terms with her, one is happy in her enlightenment, but if not she makes fun of one.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But this story also teaches how one can live on good terms with her.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Had the scholar not been married, had he been an aestheticist with all the resources at his disposal, he might have been the lucky one to whom that child prodigy wished to belong.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He would not have married; their feelings would have been too exclusive for that.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He would have built her a palace and spared no refinement to make her life rich in enjoyment, he would have visited her in her castle, for that was how she wished it to be; with erotic coquetry he would have made the journey to her on foot while his valets followed in a carriage, bringing rich and costly gifts.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In his oriental studies he would also have stumbled upon that remarkable diacritic.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He would have stared at it without being able to explain it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However, the moment had come to visit the beloved.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He would have cast aside this care, for how could he fittingly visit one who loved him with thoughts of anything but her charm and his own love?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He would have made himself all amiability, he would have been more fascinating than ever, pleased her beyond measure, because his voice bore the faint echo of many passions, and he had to make gaiety the victor over his despondency.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But when at dawn he left her, when he had thrown her the last kiss and sat now in his carriage, his brow was darkened.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He came home.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The shutters in his study were closed, the lamps lit, he declined to be disrobed but sat on and stared at that dot that he could not explain.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Indeed, he had a girl whom he loved, yes, maybe worshipped, whom he could visit when his soul was rich and strong, but not a spouse who came in and called him to dinner, not a wife who could blow the dot away.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Woman has, all in all, an innate talent and a primitive gift for clarifying finiteness, an absolute virtuosity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: When man was created he stood there, lord and master of all nature’s pomp and splendour, the entire wealth of finiteness awaiting his beck and call, but he did not know what to do with it all.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He looked at it, but it was as though everything would vanish at the glance of the spirit, it was as if all would have gone by him were he to take just one single step.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Thus he stood, an imposing figure, inwardly thoughtful but comic, for one must indeed smile at this rich man who did not know how to use his wealth, but also tragic because he could not use it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Then woman was created.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She was in no embarrassment, she knew straightaway how to tackle the matter, and without fuss or preparation she was ready straightaway to begin.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: This was the first comfort to be bestowed upon mankind.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She drew near to the man, happy as a child, humble as a child, wistful as a child.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She wanted only to be his comfort, alleviate his need, a need she did not understand and had no idea she was meeting, the need to make the interval shorter.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And lo and behold, her humble comfort became life’s richest joy, her innocent pastimes life’s beauty, her childlike play life’s deepest meaning.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Woman clarifies finiteness, man chases after infinity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So it should be, and each has his and her pain; for the woman bears children in pain, but the man conceives ideas in pain, and it is not for woman to feel the anxiety of doubt or the torment of despair.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Not that she stands outside the idea, but she has it at second-hand.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yet because woman clarifies finiteness in this way, she is man’s deepest life, but a life that must be concealed and clandestine as is always the life of the root.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For this reason I hate all that contemptible talk of the emancipation of women.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: God forbid that it should ever happen.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But it will not, it must not and cannot.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let evil spirits try it, let stupid people who have no idea what it is to be a man, of what is great or poor in that, no inkling of woman’s perfection in her imperfection!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Could there really be one single woman simple-minded and vain and pitiable enough to believe that within the category of man she could be more perfect than man, not to perceive that her loss would be irreparable?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: No base seducer could come up with a more dangerous doctrine for woman, for once he has got her to believe this she is entirely in his power, at the mercy of his caprice, she can be nothing for man but be a prey to his whims, whereas as a woman she can be everything for him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But the poor devils know not what they do, they themselves do not have what it takes to be men, and instead they would corrupt woman and be united with her on condition of remaining what they are, half-men, with woman promoted to the same miserable condition.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let man give up his claim to be lord and master of Nature, let him yield his place to woman; she is its mistress, it understands her and she understands it, it is obedient to her beckoning.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That is why she is everything for man, for she bestows finiteness upon him; without her he is an unstable spirit, an unhappy being who cannot find rest and has no place to go.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I have often rejoiced to see woman’s significance in this light; for me she then becomes a symbol of the congregation in general, and the spirit is greatly embarrassed when it has no congregation in which to dwell, and when it dwells in the congregation it becomes the spirit of the congregation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That is why  it does not say in the Scriptures that the maiden shall leave the father and mother and cleave unto her husband, as one might expect seeing woman is after all the weaker of the two and seeks protection in the man; no, it says, ‘A man shall leave his father and mother and shall cleave unto his wife’, for inasmuch as she gives him finiteness she is stronger than he.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Therefore nothing can provide as beautiful an image of the congregation as a woman.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If one saw it in this way I really believe many a prospect for the beautification of divine worship would open up.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yet what lack of taste it shows in our churches that the congregation, so far as it does not represent itself, is represented by a deacon or a bellringer!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It ought always to be represented by a woman.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But here I sit and preach, forgetting what I should really be talking about, forgetting that it is to you I should be talking.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That’s because my new friend [ – our hero – ] had put you completely out of my mind.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: With him, you see, I would happily talk about such things – for one thing he is no mocker, and for another he is a married man and only someone with an eye for the beauty of marriage will be able also to see the truth in my remarks.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So I return to our hero.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The title is one he certainly deserves, nevertheless from now on I shall not use it but prefer another designation more dear to me, in that with a sincere heart I call him my friend, just as it is my pleasure to call myself his.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So life, you see, has provided him with that ‘article of luxury known as a friend’.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Perhaps you thought I would pass over the subject of friendship and its ethical validity in silence.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Or rather, that the topic of friendship is one I would be unable to get round to, seeing it has absolutely no ethical significance and falls entirely within aesthetic categories.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Perhaps you are surprised that in discussing it at all I should do so here, for surely friendship is the first dream of youth.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You are an observer, and so you will allow the justice of my observation that a familiar character-distinction is marked by whether the period for friendship falls in very early youth or only at a later age.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: More volatile natures have no difficulty in adjusting to themselves, their selves are currency from the very start and so trade begins at once.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For those of a more profound disposition it is harder to find themselves, and so long as they have not done so they cannot wish anyone to offer them a friendship they cannot requite.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: People of this disposition are partly self-absorbed, partly observers; however, an observer is no friend.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: To those who seek the relationship of friendship at a very early age it not infrequently happens that, when love begins to assert itself, friendship fades completely.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: They find that friendship was an imperfect form, break off their earlier relations and focus their whole soul exclusively upon marriage.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Others have the opposite experience.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Those who have tasted the sweetness of love too early, savoured its joys in the intoxication of youth, perhaps acquired a false view of the opposite sex.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Perhaps they became unjust towards the opposite sex.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Maybe their frivolity cost them dear, perhaps they believed in feelings on their own part which proved not to be lasting; or believed in the feelings of others which vanished as in a dream.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So they gave up love, for them it was both too much and too little, for they had touched upon the dialectic in love without being able to resolve it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So then they chose friendship.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Both these configurations must be regarded as abnormal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: My friend is in neither situation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He had made no youthful experiments in friendship before he learnt to know love, but nor had he harmed himself by enjoying the unripe fruit of love too early.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Precisely because it was in and through his marriage that he learnt to see what is beautiful about having a friend or friends, neither has he for an instant been undecided as to how to regard friendship, or doubted that it loses its significance if not regarded ethically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You treat friendship as you do everything else.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Your soul is so little centred in the ethical that from you one can receive opposite accounts of the same thing, and your utterances bear clear witness to the truth of the proposition that sentimentality and callousness are one and the same.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Your view of friendship is best compared with a witch’s letter and anyone adopting it is bound to become as crazy as one must assume that someone proposing it already is to a degree.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: When one hears you propounding – should the humour so take you – the divinity of the love of young people, the beauty of the meeting of kindred souls, one almost fears that your sentimentality will cost you your young life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: At other times to hear you talk one might almost believe you were an old hand well versed in the hollowness and emptiness of the world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: ‘A friend,’ you say, ‘is an enigmatic thing; like fog, he can only be seen at a distance, for it is only when one becomes unhappy that one notices one has had a friend.’ It is easy to see that you base such a judgement upon friendship on a different requirement from the one you made previously.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You spoke earlier of intellectual friendship, of the beauty of a spiritual eroticism, a common passion for ideas; now you are talking of a practical friendship in everyday affairs, of mutual help in the hardships of earthly life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: There is some truth in both requirements, but if one cannot find a point of unity for them the best thing is no doubt to conclude in your main result that friendship is nonsense, a conclusion you extract in part from each of your propositions, in part from them both in their mutual opposition.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The absolute condition for friendship is full agreement in life-view.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If one has that, one will not be tempted to base one’s friendship on obscure emotions or unaccountable sympathies.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Consequently, one will not experience those ridiculous reversals, having a friend one day but not the next.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One will not give unexplained sympathy less than its due, for one does not have a friend in the strict sense in everyone with whom one shares a life-view, but neither will sympathy in its mysterious ways by itself be the basis of one’s friendships.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A true friendship always requires consciousness and that saves it from being infatuation.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The life-view in which one is united must be a positive life-view.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: As for my friend and I, we do have such a positive view in common.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So when we look at each other we do not laugh like those Augurs, we become serious.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It was quite proper for the Augurs to laugh since their common life-view was a negative one.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That you understand very well, because it is one of your quixotic wishes ‘to find a kindred soul with whom you can laugh at it all’; and ‘the awful thing, what causes one almost to be worried about life, is that practically no one notices how miserable it is, and of those few who do, it is only a quite rare exception that knows how to hold on to his good humour and laugh at it all’.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If your wish isn’t satisfied you know how to make the best of that, for ‘it is in line with the idea that only one person should laugh; such a one is the true pessimist, there being more of the kind would be proof that the world wasn’t completely wretched’.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Your thought is now in full swing and knows no limit.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You think ‘even to laugh is only an imperfect expression of the real ridicule of life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For it to be perfect one ought properly to be serious.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The most perfect mockery of life would be if the person who propounded the deepest truth were not a dreamer but a doubter.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: And that isn’t inconceivable, for no one can propound the positive truth as excellently as a doubter, except that he himself doesn’t believe in it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If he were a hypocrite the joke would be on him; if he were a doubter who perhaps wanted to believe what he doubted, the mockery would be entirely objective, existence would be mocking itself through him; he would be propounding a doctrine able to explain everything and the whole race could repose in it, but this doctrine could not explain its own founder.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Were a person clever enough to conceal the fact of his own madness, he could make the whole world mad.’ You see how difficult it is, if this is how you look at life, to find a friend with whom to share a common life-view.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Or perhaps you have found such friends in the mysterious society of Symparanekromenoi you sometimes speak of?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Could it be that you are an association of friends who mutually esteem one another precisely for being clever enough to know how to hide your madness?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So friendship requires a positive view of life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But a positive life-view is inconceivable unless it contains an ethical factor.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Certainly, in our own time one often meets people who have a system in which there is no room for the ethical.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Let them have a system ten times over, they do not have a life-view.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In our own time such a phenomenon can be explained very readily, for as it is in so many ways back-to-front, that is what it is in the case of one’s being initiated into the great mysteries before being initiated into the lesser ones.46 So really the ethical factor in the life-view is the starting-point for friendship, and only when one sees friendship thus does it acquire truth and beauty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If one is content with sympathy as something of a mystery, friendship finds its most complete expression in the relation between those lovebirds whose solidarity is so heartfelt that the death of one is also the death of the other.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Yet while such a relation is beautiful in nature it is ugly in the world of the spirit.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Unity in life-view is what constitutes friendship.
