chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If that is present it endures even if the friend dies, for the transfigured friend lives on in the other; if it ceases, the friendship is over even if the friend goes on living.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If one looks at friendship in this way, one looks at it ethically and therefore in the light of its beauty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It thus acquires both beauty and significance.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Ought I to cite an authority in my support against you?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Very well!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: How did Aristotle understand friendship?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Did he not make it the starting-point of his whole ethical view of life?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For with friendship, he says, the concepts of justice are so broadened that friendship and justice come to the same.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So he bases the concept of justice on the idea of friendship.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Consequently his category is, in a way, more perfect than the modern one which bases right on duty, on the abstract categorical;47 he bases it on the social.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: From that one sees that the idea of the State becomes the highest idea, but that again is what makes his category imperfect.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However I shall not presume here to enter into such investigations as the relation between the Aristotelian and the Kantian concepts of the ethical.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I cited Aristotle only to remind you that he, too, perceived that friendship contributes to one’s winning reality ethically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The person who looks at friendship ethically sees it as a duty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I might say, therefore, that it is every man’s duty to have a friend.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But I would rather use another expression which simultaneously conveys the ethical both in friendship and in everything else elaborated in the foregoing and, in addition, brings out sharply the difference between the ethical and the aesthetic: ‘It is every man’s duty to become revealed.’ The Scriptures teach that ‘it is appointed unto men once to die, but after this the judgement’ when everything shall be revealed.48 Ethics says it is the meaning of life and reality that man be revealed.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So if he is not, the revelation will take the form of punishment.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The aesthete, on the other hand, does not wish to give reality meaning, he remains forever concealed because, however often and however much he abandons himself to the world, he never does it totally; there is always something he holds back; if he were to do it totally he would be doing it ethically.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But wanting to play hide-and-seek in this way always avenges itself; it does that, of course, through one’s becoming a mystery to oneself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Hence all mystics, in not recognizing reality’s demand that one be revealed, stumble against difficulties and trials no other knows of.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It is as though they discovered quite another world, as though their nature acquired a replica of itself inside.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The person who will not fight with reality gets phantoms to contend with.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: With that I am through for this occasion.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It was never my intention to propound a theory of duty.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What I wanted was to show how, in the mixed regions, far from depriving life of its beauty, the ethical precisely imparts beauty to it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It affords to life peace, assurance and security, for it is constantly crying out to us: quod petis, hic est.49 It saves one from all infatuations that would exhaust the soul and it brings to it health and strength.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It teaches us not to overvalue the fortuitous or to idolize good fortune.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It teaches one to be happy in good fortune, and this is something the aesthete is incapable of, for good fortune in itself is an infinite relativity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: It teaches one to be happy in misfortune.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Just look on what I have written as a trifle, think of it as notes on Balle’s textbook; it’s of no consequence, yet it has an authority which I hope you will respect.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Or do I perhaps seem to have usurped such authority, improperly implicated my official position in this settlement of accounts, behaved as judge and not party?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I happily renounce any such claim, I am not even the party opposed to you, for while I readily admit that aesthetics could well give you power of attorney to appear on its behalf, I am far from crediting myself with the qualifications needed to speak on behalf of ethics.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I am nothing but a witness, and that is the only sense in which I meant that this letter had some authority; for a person who speaks of what he has experienced always has authority.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I am just a witness, and here you have my sworn testimony in legally appropriate form.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I perform my services as judge, I am glad to have such a vocation, I believe it is in keeping with my abilities and my whole personal being, I know it makes demands on my powers.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I try to mould myself more and more to it, and in doing so I feel that I am developing myself more and more.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I love my wife, am happy in my home.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: My work has importance for me, and I think it also has some for others, even though that is something I cannot determine and exactly measure.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I feel joy in the fact that the personal life of others has importance for me, and desire and hope that mine also has some for those with whom I am in sympathy in my whole view of life.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I love my native country, I cannot imagine thriving properly in any other.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I love my mother tongue which liberates my thought, find it an excellent means for expressing what I have to say in the world.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Thus my life has importance for me, so much so that I feel joyful and content with it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Meanwhile I live a higher life and when in the respiration of my earthly and domestic existence I occasionally inhale this higher life, I count myself blessed, art and grace come together for me.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Thus I love existence because it is beautiful, and hope for one that is more beautiful still.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Here is my testimony.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If I were in doubt as to whether to present it, it would be from concern for you, for I fear almost that it will hurt you to hear that life in its simplicity can be so beautiful.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: However, accept my testimony, let it cause you a little pain, but let it also have a joyful effect on you; it has a property which your life unfortunately lacks – dependability.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You can safely build upon it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Recently I have frequently talked with my wife about you.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She is really very fond of you  and I sympathize with her feelings in this respect, all the more since I believe that part of the reason she is kindly disposed to you is that she sees your weaknesses.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She sees clearly that what you lack is some degree of womanliness.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You are too proud to be able to give yourself up to anyone.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She is not at all attracted by your pride, for she thinks the truly greatest thing is to be able to devote oneself to others.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You may not believe it, but I actually plead in your defence against her.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: She maintains that you reject everyone because of your pride; I try to explain that perhaps it is not quite as she thinks, that you reject people in an infinite sense, that it is the restlessness with which your soul strives for the infinite that makes you unfair to people.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That is something she refuses to grasp, and I can well understand that, because when someone is as easily contented as she is – and just how easily contented you can gather from the fact, among other things, that she feels indescribably happy in being tied to me – it is hard not to condemn you.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So my marriage, too, has its conflict, and in a way you are to blame for that.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: We shall get over it and my only hope is that you never become another kind of occasion for marital strife.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But you yourself might help to decide the dispute between my wife and me.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Do not think I wish to intrude on your secrets, but I have just one question to put to you, which I think you can answer without making too free with yourself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Answer me honestly and without evasion: do you really laugh when you are alone?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You know what I mean – I do not mean whether you ever, or even often, happen to laugh when alone, but whether you find this lonely laughter satisfying?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If not, I have won the day and I am sure I can convince my wife.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Now whether in fact you do spend your time laughing when alone I do not know; still, it strikes me that it would be rather more than a little strange.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Your life may well have evolved in a way that makes you feel a need for solitude, but not, so far as I can judge, a need to laugh.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Even the most cursory observation shows that your life is planned to an unusual standard.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: You seem not at all content to follow the highways but prefer to strike out on your own.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One can easily forgive a certain adventurousness in a young man, but it is another matter when this takes the upper hand to such an extent as to make it out to be the normal and the real.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One owes it to a person who has gone astray in this way to shout: ‘Think of the end!’ and to explain that the word ‘end’ does not mean death, for even that is not a person’s hardest task, but life; to explain that the moment comes when the real question is that of beginning to live, and that therefore it is a dangerous thing to be compelled so to split oneself up that it involves the greatest of difficulty to gather oneself together again, yes, that one must do that in such a hurry and haste that one cannot pick it all up, and instead of being a person out of the ordinary one ends up being a defective specimen of humanity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In the Middle Ages one tackled this matter differently.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: One broke off life’s development abruptly and went into a monastery.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What was wrong with that was not going into a monastery but the erroneous conceptions associated with that step.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For my part, I can very well reconcile myself to a person’s making that decision, indeed I can see something rather attractive in it; but on the other hand I require of him that he can be clear what it means.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In the Middle Ages it was thought that in choosing the monastery one was choosing something uncommon and became oneself an uncommon man; from the heights of the monastery one looked down proudly, almost compassionately, upon ordinary people.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: No wonder people flocked to the monastery when it was possible to be an unusual man at such a reasonable cost!
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: But the gods do not sell the unusual at a bargain price.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If those who withdrew from life had been honest and sincere with themselves and others, if they had loved being a human being more than all else, if they had felt with passion all the beauty that lies in that, if their hearts had not been unacquainted with the true, deep feeling for humanity, perhaps they might still have withdrawn into the solitude of the monastery, but they would not have foolishly imagined they had become unusual people except in the sense that they were less perfect than others; they would not have looked down with compassion on the ordinary, but regarded them sympathetically, in wistful joy at having succeeded in perfecting the beautiful and the great in a way that they themselves were not capable of.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In our own time the monastic life has fallen in price; so one rarely sees someone make a clean break with the whole of existence, with all the universally human.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: On the other hand, if one has some knowledge of people one occasionally finds in a particular individual a heresy which calls the monastic theory vividly to mind.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For the record, I will now give you my view of what a man out of the common is.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The truly extraordinary man is the truly ordinary man.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The more of the universally human an individual is able to realize in his life, the more extraordinary he is.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The less of the universal he is able to assume, the less perfect he is.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Uncommon he may be, but not in a good sense.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: So if a person who wants to realize the task that everyone is assigned – that of expressing the universally human in his individual life – stumbles on difficulties, if it looks as though there is something of the universal that he is unable to assume into his life, what does he do?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If the monastery theory haunts his mind, or some aesthetic view quite analogous to it, he will be happy; from the very first moment he feels in all his exclusiveness that he is an exception, an uncommon person, it makes him vain, as childish as if a nightingale which had a red feather in its wing were to rejoice because no other nightingale had the like.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If, on the other hand, his soul is ennobled by love of the universal, if he loves man’s existence in this world, what then does he do?
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He deliberates how far it is true.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: A man may have himself to blame for this imperfection, or he can have it quite blamelessly, but it can still be true that he cannot realize the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If people were in general more energetically self-aware then perhaps many more would arrive at the same conclusion.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will also know how laziness and cowardice can make a person fancy it is true, and make the pain of it into a thing of no consequence by transforming the universal into the particular and preserving an abstract possibility in relation to the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For the universal exists nowhere as such, and it is up to me, to the energy of my consciousness, whether I see the universal in the particular or merely the particular.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Perhaps such a deliberation will not strike him as being enough, and he will risk an experiment.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will realize that if the experiment leads him to the same conclusion, the truth will be impressed upon him all the more emphatically, and if he wants to coddle himself perhaps he would do better to desist, since he will come to groan more than ever.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will know that nothing particular is the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: In order not to delude himself, then, he will transform the particular into the universal, he will see in the particular much more than is contained in it as such; for him it is the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will come to the aid of the particular and give it significance as the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Then if he notices that the experiment is failing, he will have arranged everything so that what wounds him is not the particular but the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will watch over himself so that no mix-up occurs, so that it is not the particular that comes to wound him, for its wound will be too light and he will love himself in too serious a way for the most pressing thing to be to receive a light wound; he will love the universal too sincerely to want to replace it with the particular so as to slip away unscathed.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will be on his guard not to smile at the impotent reaction of the particular, he will take care not to look at the matter irresponsibly even though the particular as such tempts him to do so; he will not let himself be distracted by the strange misunderstanding that in him the particular has a greater friend than it has in itself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Having done that, he will go calmly to meet the pain; however much his consciousness is shaken, it does not waver.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Now if it happens that the universal he cannot realize is just the thing he wants, then in a sense, if he is a magnanimous person, that will make him glad.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Then he will say: ‘I have fought under the most unfavourable conditions possible.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I have fought with the particular, I have set my desire on the side of the enemy, and to make it complete I have made the particular into the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: That all this will make the defeat harder for me is true, but it will also strengthen my consciousness, it will give it energy and clarity.’ Thus he has emancipated himself from the universal on this point.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Not for an instant will he be unclear what such a step means; after all, it was he himself who made the defeat complete and gave it meaning, for he knew where he was vulnerable and how, and he brought the wound upon himself; which the particular in itself could not do.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will then be assured that there is something of the universal that he cannot realize.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: With this assurance, however, he is not through, because it will engender a deep sorrow in his soul.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will rejoice in the others to whom it was granted to accomplish this thing, he will see perhaps better than they do how beautiful it is, but he himself will sorrow, not in a cowardly and dispirited way, but deeply and frankly, for he will say: ‘After all, I love the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: If it were the happy lot of others to bear witness to the universal by realizing it, very well then, I bear witness to it with my sorrow, and the deeper I sorrow the more significant my witness.’ And this sorrow is beautiful, is itself an expression of the universally human, a beating of its heart within him, and will reconcile him with it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: With this assurance that he has won he is still not through, for he will feel that he has laid a great responsibility upon himself.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: ‘At this point,’ he says, ‘I have put myself outside the universal, I have deprived myself of the guidance, the security and reassurance which the universal gives.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: I stand alone, without sympathy, for I am an exception.’ But he will not become faint-hearted and disconsolate, he will walk his lonely path with poise, for after all he has produced the evidence of the rightness of what he did, he has his pain.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will not be unclear concerning this step, he possesses an explanation which he will be able to proffer at any time; no tumult can confuse it for him, no absence of mind; if he awoke in the middle of the night he would still be able instantly to render himself an account of everything.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will feel that the upbringing that has fallen to his lot is hard, for the universal is a severe master when one has it outside one; it is constantly holding over him the sword of justice, saying, ‘Why do you want to be outside?’, and even though he says, ‘It is not my fault’, it still makes him accountable for it and makes its claims on him.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He will then return to the same point from time to time, produce the evidence again and again, and then go cheerfully on.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: He reposes in his hard-earned conviction and will say, ‘What in the last resort I rely on is that there exists a righteous rationality and I will place my trust in its compassion, that it is compassionate enough to show justice, for it would not be so dreadful to suffer a punishment I had deserved because I did wrong, but it would be dreadful if I were able to do wrong in such a way that no one punished it, and the dreadful thing would not be that I awoke in my heart’s delusion with anguish and terror, but that I could delude my heart in a way that no one could awaken it.’ This whole struggle, however, is a purgatory, of whose horror I can at least form a conception.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: People should therefore not be so eagerly ambitious to become something out of the common, for being that means something else than a capricious satisfaction of one’s arbitrary desire.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: The person who, on the other hand, was convinced in pain that he was an uncommon man is reconciled with the universal again through his sorrow at being so; one day he may experience the joy that what caused him pain and made him lowly in his own eyes proves to be an occasion for his being lifted up again and becoming an uncommon man in a nobler sense.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: What he lost in compass perhaps he gained in inward intensity.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For not every person whose life expresses the universal indifferently is for that reason uncommon, for that would be to idolize triviality.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: For him truthfully to be called uncommon one must first inquire about the intensive power with which he does it.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: Now, the person we were speaking of will possess that power at the points where he can realize the universal.
chapter_text: Equilibrium Between the Aesthetic and the Ethical in the Development of Personality

sentence: 3 LAST WORD    PERHAPS you have the same experience with my previous letters as I have: you have forgotten most of what was in them.
If so, I trust you are in the same case as myself and able at all times, through shifts of mood, to render account to yourself of the thought and the movement.
The expression, the presentation, the embellishment, are the same yet not the same from one year to the next, like a flower, but the bearing, the movement, the stance are unchanged.
Were I to write to you now I would perhaps express myself differently.
I might even rise to eloquence somewhere in my letters, something I certainly have no pretensions to and which my position in life doesn’t demand of me either.

Were I to write now I might perhaps succeed in some other way, I don’t know, for expression is a gift and ‘every age and every year has its own flowering spring’.1 As for the thought, however, it is and remains, and I hope in the course of time the movements will become easier for me and more natural, unchanged even when they are mute because the flower of expression has been shed.

However, it is not to write you a new letter I take up my pen, but the thought of you was brought vividly to my mind by a letter I myself have received from an older friend who is a priest in Jutland.
As far as I know you have never met him.
My friendship with him goes back to my schooldays, and although there were five or six years between us, we were on a fairly intimate footing.
He was a little, thickset figure, cheerful, light-hearted, and uncommonly jovial.
Although a serious soul deep down, his outward life seemed to conform pretty well with the injunction not to ‘give a damn’.

Learning fascinated him but he wasn’t one for exams, and in his theology finals he managed no better than haud illaudabilis.2 About four years ago he was stuck in a little parish on the Jutland moors.
Outwardly he had a stentorian voice, inwardly an originality that made him always stand out in the small circle of my acquaintances.
No wonder, then, that to begin with he didn’t really feel content and thought his work too trifling for him.
Now, however, he has regained his contentment, and reading a letter I received from him just recently had a really most encouraging effect on me.
‘The Jutland moor,’ he says, ‘is, after all, a good exercise ground for me and an incomparable study.
I go walking there on Saturdays and meditate on my sermons, and everything expands before me.

I forget my real audience and gain an ideal one, I manage to become totally self-absorbed, so that when I step up into the pulpit it is as though I were still standing on the moor where my eye can find no one, where my voice lifts itself with all its strength to drown out the storm.’ Still, it isn’t to tell you this that I write, but to send you one of his sermons that I found enclosed in the letter.
I haven’t wanted to show it to you personally, so as not to provoke your criticism, but send you the manuscript to let it make its impression on you in tranquillity.
He has not given it yet, but means to do so next year and is confident he will make every farmer understand it.
You are not to sneeze at it for that reason, for the beauty of the universal consists precisely in everyone being able to understand it.
In this sermon he has grasped what I was saying to you and what I would have liked to say; he has expressed it more felicitously than I find myself capable of.
Take it, then, read it; I have nothing to add, except that I have read it and thought of myself, and thought of you.
4 THE EDIFYING IN THE   THOUGHT THAT AGAINST GOD   WE ARE ALWAYS IN THE WRONG    Prayer FATHER in Heaven!
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: So the edifying, then, is to be always in the wrong, for only the infinite edifies, the finite does not!
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: If, then, there were a human being you loved, even if your love succeeded in piously deluding your thought and yourself, you would nevertheless be in a constant contradiction, because you would know you were in the right but wanted to be – and wanted to believe you were – in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: If, on the other hand, it was God you loved, could there then be any question of such a contradiction?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Could what you knew then be anything but what you wanted to believe?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Could it be that He who is in heaven is not greater than you who dwell on earth, that His wealth is not more abundant than your sufficiency, His wisdom not more profound than your shrewdness, His holiness not greater than your righteousness?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Must you not of necessity recognize this?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: But if you must recognize it there is no contradiction between your knowledge and your wish.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: And yet, if you must necessarily recognize it then there is indeed no edification in the thought that you are always in the wrong, for it was said that the reason why it could prove painful on one occasion to be in the wrong and edifying on another was that in the one case one is compelled to recognize what in the other case one wanted to recognize.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: So you would indeed be freed in your relationship to God from the contradiction, but you would have lost the edification; yet that was precisely what we were to consider: what is edifying in being always in the wrong against God.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Is it really so?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Why did you wish to be in the wrong against a human being?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Because you loved!
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Why did you find it edifying?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Because you loved!
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: The more you loved, the less time you had to consider whether you were in the right or not; your love had but one wish, that you might always be in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: So, too, in your relation to God.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: You loved God, and therefore your soul could only find repose and joy in the thought that you must always be in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: So it was not through the trials of thought that you came to this recognition, you were not compelled, for when you are in love you are in freedom.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: So if thought did convince you that the situation was as you wanted it, that there was nothing for it but that you must always be in the wrong or that God must always be in the right, that followed later, for you did not arrive at the certainty that you were in the wrong from the recognition that God is in the right.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: It was from love’s highest and only wish that you might always be in the wrong that you came to the recognition that God is always in the right.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: But that wish is a matter of love and therefore of freedom, and so you are by no means compelled to recognize that you were always in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: So you were not made certain that you were always in the wrong by reflection; the certainty came from your being edified by that thought.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: It is an edifying thought, then, that against God we are always in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: If this conviction did not have its source in your whole being, that is, in the love that is within you, your reflection would have acquired a different appearance.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: You would have recognized that God is always in the right, this you would have been compelled to recognize; as a consequence of that, you would have been compelled to recognize that you are always in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: The latter would have already caused difficulties, for although you can certainly be compelled to recognize that God is always in the right, you cannot really be compelled to apply this to yourself, to let your whole being appropriate this recognition.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: So you would have recognized that God is always in the right and, in consequence of that, that you are always in the wrong, but this recognition would not have edified you.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: There is nothing edifying in recognizing that God is always in the right, and neither, therefore, in any thought that follows necessarily from it.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: In that case, when you recognize that God is always in the right, you are standing outside God, and similarly when in consequence you recognize that you are always in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: If, on the other hand, on the strength of no precedent recognition you claim, and are convinced, that you are always in the wrong, you are hidden in God.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: This is your divine worship, your religious devotion, your reverence for God.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: You loved a human being, you wished always to be in the wrong against him; alas!
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: he was unfaithful to you, and however reluctantly, however much it pained you, you were nevertheless shown to be in the right against him, and in the wrong in loving him so dearly.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: And yet your soul demanded to love in that way, only in that way could you find peace and rest and happiness.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Your soul then turned away from the finite to the infinite; there it found its object, there your love became happy.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: I will love God, you said, He gives the lover everything, He fulfils my dearest, my only wish, that against Him I am always in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Never shall any anxious doubt tear me away from Him, never will the thought terrify me that I might prove to be in the right against Him, against God I am always in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Is it not so?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Was this not your only wish, your dearest wish?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Was it not the case that a dreadful fear seized you when for a moment the thought could arise in your soul that it was possible you were in the right, that wisdom was not the governance of God but your own plans, that righteousness was not God’s thoughts but your own achievements, that love was not God’s heart but your own emotions?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: And was it not your bliss that you could never love as you were loved?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: This thought, then, that you are always in the wrong against God, is not a truth you are forced to recognize, not a comfort to soothe your pain, not a substitute for something better; it is the joy in which you triumph over yourself and over the world, your rapture, your song of praise, your worship, a proof that your love is happy as is only that love with which one loves God.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: That against God we are always in the wrong is, then, an edifying thought; it is edifying that we are in the wrong, edifying that we always are.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: It proves its power to edify in a twofold way, partly by staying doubt and alleviating its anxieties, partly by inciting to action.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Perhaps you still recall, my hearer, a wise saying we mentioned earlier.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: It seemed so trusty and dependable, it explained everything so easily, it was ready to give everyone safe conduct through life unmoved by the storms of doubt.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: ‘One does what one can,’ it called out to the perplexed.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: And it is indeed undeniable that it helps just to do that.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Beyond that it had nothing to say, it vanished like a dream, or became a monotonous repetition in the doubter’s ear.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Then when he wanted to use it, it turned out that he could not, that it entangled him in a mesh of difficulties.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: He could find no time to ponder what he could do, because he had at the same time to be doing what he could.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Or if he found time to ponder, the scrutiny gave him a more-or-less, an approximation, but never anything exhaustive.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: And how is a man to measure his relation to God with a more or less, or with an approximation?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: He then convinced himself that this wise saying was a treacherous friend which, under the guise of helping him, enfolded him in doubt, frightened him into a perpetual cycle of confusion.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: What before had been obscure to him but did not cause him worry, now became no clearer but made his mind troubled and anxious.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Only in an infinite relation to God could the doubt be allayed; only in an infinitely free relation to God could his trouble be turned into joy.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: He is in an infinite relation to God when he recognizes that God is always in the right, in an infinitely free relation when he recognizes that he himself is always in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: The doubt is then stayed, for the movement of doubt lay precisely in his being at one moment in the right, at the next in the wrong, being to some extent in the right, to some extent in the wrong, and that was meant to signify his relation to God.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: But a relation like that is no relation, and that was what gave food for doubt.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: In his relation to another human being, it was indeed possible to be partly in the wrong, partly in the right, to some extent in the wrong, to some extent in the right, because he himself, like every human being, is finite, and his relation is a finite relation which consists in a more-or-less.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: He remained in doubt, therefore, so long as doubt made the infinite relation finite, and as long as the wise saying filled the infinite relation with finitude.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: So whenever doubt makes him anxious with the particular, whenever it teaches him that he suffers too much or is tried beyond his powers, he forgets the finite in the infinite thought that he is always in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Every time the anxiety of doubt makes him sorrowful, he lifts himself above the finite into the infinite, for this thought that he is always in the wrong is the wing on which he soars over finitude, it is the longing with which he seeks God, it is the love in which he finds God.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: So against God we are always in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: But is this not an anaesthetizing thought?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: However edifying it may be for man, is it not dangerous, does it not lull him into a sleep in which he dreams of a relationship to God which is nevertheless no real relationship, does it not consume the power of his will and the strength of his purpose?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: By no means!
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Was the man who wished always to be in the wrong against another man, dull and inactive?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Did he not do everything in his power to be in the right and yet wanted only to be in the wrong?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Should the thought that against God we are always in the wrong not then be an inspiring one?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: For what does it express other than that God’s love is always greater than our love?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Does this thought not make him happy to act?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: For when he doubts he has no strength to act.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Does it not make him fervent in his spirit, since when he makes finite calculations the fire of the spirit is quenched?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Then if, my hearer, your only wish were denied you, still you are glad; you do not say, ‘God is always in the right’, for there is no jubilation in that; you say, ‘Against God I am always in the wrong.’ If what you wished was what others, and you yourself in a sense, might call your duty, if you were not only to forgo your wish but in a sense be unfaithful to your duty, if you lost not merely your joy but honour itself, still you are glad; ‘Against God,’ you say, ‘I am always in the wrong.’ If you knocked but it was not opened unto you, if you sought but did not find, if you laboured but nothing gained, if you planted and watered but saw no blessing, if heaven were closed and the witness failed to appear, still you are glad in your works.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: If the punishment which the sins of the fathers had called down were to fall upon you, still you are glad, for against God we are always in the wrong.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Against God we are always in the wrong; this thought then stays the doubt and alleviates its anxiety, it puts one in heart and inspires one to action.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Your thought has now followed the course of this exposition, perhaps hurrying on ahead when it followed familiar paths; it gave you the lead, slowly, perhaps reluctantly, when the way was unfamiliar, but nevertheless you must admit this: that it is as it was set forth, and your thought had no objections.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Before we part, one more question, my hearer: did you wish, could you wish, that it were otherwise?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Could you wish that you were in the right, could you wish that that beautiful law which for thousands of years has borne the human race and every generation of the race through life, that beautiful law, more glorious than that which keeps the stars in their courses across the vault of heaven, could you wish that law breached – more dreadful than if the law of Nature lost its force and everything was dissolved in terrible chaos?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Could you wish that?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: I have no words of wrath with which to terrify you.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Your wish must not proceed from dread of the blasphemy of the thought of wanting to be in the right against God.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: I ask you simply, could you wish that it were otherwise?
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Perhaps my voice is not strong and warm enough to penetrate to your inmost thought; ah!
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: but ask yourself, ask yourself with the solemn uncertainty with which you would address a person you knew was capable of deciding your life’s happiness with a single word, ask yourself even more seriously, for in truth it is a question of salvation.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Stay not the flight of your soul, do not sadden what is your better part, do not enervate your soul with half wishes and half thoughts.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong

sentence: Ask yourself, and keep on asking until you find the answer, for one can recognize a thing many times and acknowledge it, one can want a thing many times and attempt it, yet only the deep inner movement, only the indescribable motions of the heart, only these convince you that what you have recognized ‘belongs unto you’, that no power can take it from you; for only the truth that edifies is truth for you.
chapter_text: The Edifying in the Thought that Against God We Are Always in the Wrong
